CSJ Jie-A-Joen, MSc', 'dr.mr. R Snoeij', 'mr. A Schoneveld', 'mr. J van Poppel', 'mr.dr. EW Ros', 'prof.dr. MF de Wilde, LL.M', 'R Bakker']",,"Inhoud

column1: In het vak Inleiding internationaal en Europees belastingrecht komt de heffing van inkomsten-, dividend- en vennootschapsbelasting in Nederland aan de orde. Dit, in situaties waarin natuurlijke personen en lichamen inkomsten of ondernemingswinsten behalen in een grensoverschrijdende omgeving.

Eerst komt de werking en toepassing van het Nederlands internationaal belastingrecht aan de orde. Er wordt ingegaan op de Nederlandse belastingwetgeving waarin de belastingverplichtingen zijn geregeld voor personen met een buitenlandse woonplaats of nationaliteit die in Nederland belastbare inkomsten behalen. Ook wordt de nationale belastingwetgeving behandeld waarin de belastingverplichtingen geregeld zijn voor inwoners van Nederland of personen met een Nederlandse nationaliteit die in het buitenland belastbare inkomsten behalen. Daarnaast worden de door Nederland met andere landen gesloten belastingverdragen besproken. Hierin wordt geregeld welke van de verdragsluitende staten bevoegd is om de behaalde inkomsten in dergelijke internationale situaties te belasten en welke gehouden is om terug te treden en een zogenoemde vermindering ter voorkoming van dubbele belasting moet verlenen. Als kapstok wordt het OESO Modelverdrag gebruikt, het model dat de basis vormt voor de door Nederland gesloten verdragen. De basisbegrippen van het internationaal belastingrecht worden besproken. Ook wordt ingegaan op de (beleids)keuzes c.q. uitwerkingen die in het OESO Modelverdrag en de Nederlandse belastingverdragen tot uitdrukking zijn gebracht. Verder wordt ingegaan op het door Nederland ondertekende multilaterale anti-BEPS verdrag (Multilateral Convention to Implement Tax Treaty Related Measures to Prevent BEPS). Specifieke aandacht komt toe aan het thema ‘transfer pricing.’

Vervolgens wordt ingegaan op de invloed van het recht van de Europese Unie op de heffing van directe belastingen in Nederland. Er wordt enerzijds ingegaan op de werking en toepassing van het primaire recht van de Europese Unie in dit verband. De fundamentele vrijheden worden besproken. Het toetsingskader van het Europese Hof van Justitie wordt behandeld. Ook het staatssteunverbod wordt belicht en zal het EU-arbitrageverdrag kort worden belicht. Anderzijds wordt ingegaan op de invloed van het secundaire Unierecht, de EU-richtlijnen, op de heffing van directe belastingen in Nederland.

Deze rechtsgebieden worden niet alleen op individuele merites besproken. Zij worden op geïntegreerde wijze behandeld. De basisbeginselen van het internationaal belastingrecht, in hun uitwerking zowel binnen Nederland als in OESO-verband, worden telkens afgezet tegenover de aanpak binnen de Europese Unie. Alleen zo kan de uiteindelijke rechtspositie van een belastingplichtige met internationale inkomsten worden bepaald.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Na dit blok kan de student onder verwijzing naar relevante wetgeving en jurisprudentie:

column2: • de uitgangspunten en fundamenten van de rechtsgebieden van het internationaal belastingrecht en Europees belastingrecht benoemen. Dit, voor deze rechtsgebieden zowel op individuele merites als in hun onderlinge samenhang;
• het onderscheid maken tussen nationaalrechtelijke 'heffingsrechten' en fiscaal verdragsrechtelijke 'heffingsbevoegdheden'.
• de rechtsgevolgen analyseren van de toepassing van het internationaal en Europees belastingrecht in een concreet en complex feitenstel;
• de werking en toepassing van de rechtsgebieden van het internationaal en Europees belastingrecht beoordelen in een bredere juridische context;

• een gemotiveerde Engelstalige productie schrijven op academisch niveau, waarin de internationaal-belastingrechtelijke rechtsgevolgen op het gebied van de transfer pricing in een concreet feitenstel tot uitdrukking worden gebracht.

CSJ Jie-A-Joen, MSc', 'dr.mr. R Snoeij', 'mr. A Schoneveld', 'mr. J van Poppel', 'mr.dr. EW Ros', 'prof.dr. MF de Wilde, LL.M', 'R Bakker']",,"Inhoud

column1: In het onderdeel internationaal belastingrecht wordt aandacht besteed aan de oorzaken van dubbele internationale belasting en aan eventuele heffingstekorten in internationaal verband. Dit wordt bezien vanuit het nationale recht en vanuit de regelingen ter voorkoming van dubbele belasting. Er wordt ingegaan op de regels ter voorkoming van dubbele belasting, zowel in verdragssituaties als in niet-verdragssituaties. Tevens komt ook een aantal meer formeelrechtelijke aspecten aan de orde. Wat betreft het EU belastingrecht gaat het er vooral om dat fiscale regelgeving niet in strijd mag zijn met de verdragsvrijheden. Er wordt dan ook uitvoerig ingegaan op de samenhang tussen de verkeersvrijheden en de fiscale regelgeving. Daarbij passeert een groot aantal arresten van het Hof van Justitie de revue. Tevens wordt ingegaan op fiscale regelgeving op EU-niveau, bestaande uit diverse richtlijnen. Andere thema's die de revue passeren zijn de staatssteunregels en formeelrechtelijke aspecten van het EU-recht. Al deze onderwerpen worden op hoofdlijnen besproken. De verdiepingen komen aan de orde in de Master vakken Internationaal en Europees belastingrecht. Het vak beval o.a. de volgende onderwerpen:

column2: • Begrippenapparaat + interpretatiemethoden
• Beginselen van internationaal belastingrecht
• Methoden van internationaal belastingrecht
• Regelingen ter voorkoming van dubbele belastingheffing
• Verdeling van heffingsbevoegdheden in verdragen e.d.
• Beginselen van het Europees recht
• Verkeersvrijheden in het VwEU
• Fiscale EU-richtlijnen
• Staatssteun in het VwEU
• Wisselwerking tussen Europees recht en nationaal fiscaal recht
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Inzicht verwerven in de algemene beginselen van het internationaal en EU belastingrecht.
• Inzicht verkrijgen in de relevante regelgeving op nationaal en internationaal fiscaal terrein.
• Inzicht verkrijgen in de belangrijkste rechtspraak op internationaal en Europeesrechtelijk terrein.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om aan de hand van het internationale en het EU belastingrecht eenvoudige grensoverschrijdende situaties te analyseren.
• Het kritische vermogen ontwikkelen om op zelfstandige wijze vanuit internationaal en Europeesrechtelijk perspectief naar nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te kijken.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

</style>

column1: De afgelopen jaren is het internationaal strafrecht zowel in omvang als betekenis toegenomen. Dit is grotendeels het gevolg van de ‘globalisering’ en daarmee ook van het (straf)recht. Er zal worden ingegaan op de traditionele instrumenten van het internationaal strafrecht: rechtsmacht, de uitlevering, de overdracht en overname van strafvervolging, de overdracht en tenuitvoerlegging van strafvonnissen en de kleine rechtshulp in strafzaken (politiële en justitiële rechtshulp). Daarnaast zal bijzondere aandacht worden geschonken aan het internationale strafrecht binnen de Europese Unie door middel van het Europees Arrestatiebevel en het Europees Onderzoeksbevel alsmede aan overige ontwikkelingen in de Europese rechtsruimte. Tevens zullen ontwikkelingen in de strafrechtelijke afdoening van internationale misdrijven worden besproken.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: Door de toename van het internationale handelsverkeer wordt het Internationaal privaatrecht (IPR) steeds belangrijker. Het IPR omvat het samenstel van regels die privaatrechtelijke

rechtsverhoudingen met internationale elementen bestrijken. Het gaat daarbij in het bijzonder om de vraag van het toepasselijke recht en de vraag naar de bevoegdheid van de rechter. Welk recht is bijvoorbeeld van toepassing op een verpanding in het buitenland van aandelen in een Nederlandse vennootschap.

Tijdens het hoorcollege worden de algemene leerstukken en begrippen van het IPR besproken, zulks aan de hand van jurisprudentie en gevallen uit de praktijk. Door toepassing van de theorie op praktijkgevallen wordt tegelijkertijd inzicht verworven op het terrein van IPR-vragen bij zakenrecht, verbintenissenrecht, rechtspersonenrecht en burgerlijk procesrecht. De casuscolleges stellen de studenten in de gelegenheid enige vaardigheid te verwerven in het oplossen van casusposities op het terrein van het IPR aan de hand van de schriftelijke opgaven, die in de syllabus zijn afgedrukt.

column1: Na afloop van dit vak kan de student:

column2: • De verschillende rechtsregels die behoren tot het IPR op nationaal, Europees en internationaal niveau toepassen op internationale commerciële geschillen.
• IPR-uitspraken afkomstig van de Nederlandse rechter en het Europese Hof van Justitie kritisch becommentariëren en gebruiken bij het oplossen van internationale geschillen uit de praktijk.
• De juridische methodologie van het internationaal privaatrecht begrijpen en de drie hoofdvragen uit het IPR onderscheiden en beantwoorden.
• De diverse bronnen van het Nederlandse IPR en van internationale organisaties die zich inspannen voor harmonisering van IPR-regelgeving, raadplegen.
• De werking van het IPR in de praktijk toelichten en het belang van regelgeving in het IPR aangeven.
• Het IPR in bredere verbanden, zoals het Nederlandse IPR met het IPR van andere landen en het IPR in de context van de mondialisering van het recht, onderkennen en analyseren.

column1: Door de toename van het internationale handels- en rechtsverkeer wordt het internationaal privaatrecht (IPR) steeds belangrijker. Het IPR omvat het samenstel van regels die privaatrechtelijke rechtsverhoudingen met internationale elementen bestrijken. Het gaat daarbij in het bijzonder om de vraag van het toepasselijke recht, de vraag naar de bevoegdheid van de rechter en de vraag naar grensoverschrijdende erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging van vonnissen. Welk recht is bijvoorbeeld van toepassing op een arbeidsovereenkomst tussen een Nederlandse werkgever en een in Frankrijk wonende werknemer? Welke rechter is bevoegd ten aanzien van een loonvordering van de werknemer tegen de werkgever? Kan een door de Franse rechter gewezen veroordelend vonnis in Nederland ten uitvoer worden gelegd? Op familierechtelijk terrein duiken gelijkaardige vragen op. Welk recht is bijvoorbeeld van toepassing op het huwelijksgoederenregime van een Belgische man die in 1989 in Frankrijk met een Nederlandse vrouw is gehuwd? En kan een door de Spaanse rechter uitgesproken echtscheiding in Nederland worden erkend?

Tijdens het hoorcollege wordt een aantal algemene leerstukken en begrippen van het IPR besproken aan de hand van jurisprudentie en gevallen uit de praktijk. Door toepassing van de theorie op praktijkgevallen wordt tegelijkertijd inzicht verworven op het terrein van IPR-vragen bij personenrecht, zakenrecht, erfrecht en huwelijksgoederenrecht, verbintenissenrecht, rechtspersonenrecht, insolventierecht en burgerlijk procesrecht.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
De student is na afloop van dit vak in staat tot het:

column2: • analyseren, interpreteren en oplossen van casusposities op het gebied van het internationaal privaatrecht, in het bijzonder: (a) internationale arbitrage (b) onderneming- en insolventierechtelijke vraagstukken alsmede (d) internationaal personen-, familie- en erfrecht;
• onderscheiden en beantwoorden van de drie hoofdvragen van het IPR (bevoegdheid, toepasselijk recht en erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging);
• begrijpen van de juridische methodologie van het internationaal privaatrecht;
• toepassen van de relevante nationale, Europese en internationale IPR-regels;

• kritisch becommentariëren van IPR-uitspraken afkomstig van de Nederlandse rechter en het Europese Hof van Justitie en het gebruiken van deze uitspraken bij het oplossen van internationale geschillen uit de praktijk;
• begrijpen hoe de werking van het IPR is in de praktijk;
• begrijpen van het belang van regelgeving in het IPR;
• duiden van actuele ontwikkelingen op het gebied van IPR-wetgeving en –rechtspraak;
• onderkennen en analyseren van het IPR in bredere verbanden, zoals het Nederlandse IPR met het IPR van andere landen en het IPR in de context van de mondialisering van het recht.

<body>The course will provide an in-depth discussion on international art markets, and will outline the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution, consumption and valuation of different art forms will be discussed: price-setting mechanisms, segmentation of the art market, globalization of the art trade, the role of intermediaries and galleries, art as investment, etc. Special attention will be devoted to emerging art markets, and how they are impacting the international art market system. The seminars provide a guide to the subject matter and set out foundations on which students can build. The weekly class meetings depend on active participation by the students and provide the opportunity for in-depth discussion of key issues and optional topics from which the students can choose according to their own interests.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will confront master students with current research in the functioning of modern art markets. Students will be exposed to recent theoretical insights and research methods particularly drawing from the field of cultural economics. We will discuss relevant literature on the various subjects through lectures, student presentations and class discussion. Finally, the participants will focus on one topic and carry out individual research based on scholarly literature and (on-line) databases such as artprice.com, resulting in a final essay.</body>

column1: The aim of the course is to introduce students to theories of international business as part of the Global Thinkers block and is the first of three interrelated courses. The course will cover topics relating with international business theory, ownership structure, IPOs, institutional investor, regulatory reforms, stakeholder involvement and corporate social responsibility. Some of the theory included are Agency theory; Transaction costs economics; Stakeholder theory; Stewardship theory; Institutional theory; Political theory as well as Network governance and case studies/ examples real life corporate stories.
The course will include lectures combining theory, cases and live examples including a project, for students to analyze, discuss and present on during seminar sessions and workshops.

Students will be expected to be active participants in exploring real instances of effect of governance issues on actual entrepreneurial firms of all sizes but with particular attention to smaller and family enterprises.

Students will be encouraged to make use of provided articles, case studies but also to explore themes and topics by accessing news sites, databases and public informational depositories in a guided but self-proactive environment

column1: This course familiarizes you with the lanscape, culture and the business environment of the Netherlands: past, present and future. You will get to know different Dutch companies and organisations, each covering a different aspect of developing and doing international business in and from the Netherlands.

column1: At the end of this course the student of the International Exchange is able to:

column2: • Understand how the landscape, in particular the relationship between water and land, has shaped Dutch culture and industrial development.
• Understand Dutch company types, basic constructs and employer-employee relationships.
• Understand, describe, analyse and compare the core business models of a number of Dutch companies and show how they address new business development through innovation.
• Create and recommend proposals for how the Netherlands might thrive despite the impact of climate change (rising sea levels, sudden rainfall and warming).
• Apply the power of diversity and team based cooperation within a group of different nationalities from all over the world.
<title></title>

column1: Effective decision-making in an international business environment requires understanding the operation of different types of market economies and institutions of regional economic governance. This course is designed to provide you with an understanding of the institutional (or non-market) environment in which international businesses operate.

The course is divided in two parts. In the first part, we study business and politics in the European Union.  In particular, we analyse how ongoing debates (for example, on Brexit, the relationship with China, EMU, or the rise in populism) impact businesses in the European Union.  In the second part of the course we study the comparative political economy of ‘varieties of capitalism’. In particular, we examine the institutions and functioning of capitalist systems in coordinated, liberal and/or emerging market economies. Furthermore, we study the process of transition to a modern and open capitalist economy from a closed system.  Finally, we will be learning about thematic issues, such as intercultural management challenges or lobbying practices in a foreign environment.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • to develop an understanding about how the world of (international) politics and business are intertwined
• to analyze differences in rules of the game in different types of market economies
• to assess different paths to and constraints on implementing market reforms
• to understand the multilevel governance structure of the European Union and its impact on
• the business environment in Europe
• to understand the dynamics of management across cultures

column1: In this course, students will explore the interface between multilateral institutions, non-government actors, and the private sector, with a focus on the World Trade Organization (WTO). Global trade hit a record high of $28.5 trillion in 2021. Most of trade flows occur between WTO members, meaning that the activities of most if not all private sector actors are regulated by agreements signed by WTO member states. However, in contrast to the role of national formal (e.g., national rules and regulations) and informal (e.g., culture) institutions, the business relevance of such multilateral institutions is often insufficiently understood by future leaders.

The International Business Landscape course is designed to address this knowledge gap. The objective of this course is to broaden students’ understanding of multilateral institutions with a focus on the WTO, global trade policies, and their impacts on businesses. Special emphasis is laid on advancing students understanding regarding how special interests (e.g., private sector and civil society) influence international and national regulatory frameworks. Moreover, the course seeks to advance students appreciation for the complexity of ‘doing international business’ in a ‘rule-based’ global economy.

In terms of teaching, the emphasis of this course is on experiential learning. To that end, the course includes a two-day roleplay, whereby students will negotiate an international framework for global trade. In line with RSM’s mission, the focus of the roleplay will be on negotiating an international regulatory framework that aligns the WTO with global efforts to mitigate and adapt to climate change. For example, students will negotiate on issues such as tariff and non-tariff barriers for climate-friendly technologies.

• Apply public speaking skills in an international setting.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100040,2021,International Business and Nation-states,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. L Green', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. V Baptist', 'prof.dr. B Wubs', 'R van Lent, MSc']",,"Inhoud
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

Multinationals and their role in the process of globalization have attracted a great deal of attention from business historians. The origins of modern multinationals, and consequently foreign direct investment (FDI), lay in the second half of the nineteenth century, although the Dutch East India Company (VOC), set up in 1602, is often considered to be the first multinational. However, the    growth of large scale, mainly industrial multinationals, concurred with the emergence of the first   liberal global economy. Trade protectionism, which represented a partial departure from liberalism, served to stimulate multinational manufacturing as well, because companies opened factories in protected markets. World War I was a turning point in the development of a global economy and the end of free trade. Yet multinationals continued to operate and even expanded during the 1920s and 1930s. After World War II multinationals began to play a key role in the world economy. As multinationals by definition operate in at least two different nations they necessarily have to deal with two different governments. Because of this interaction, there may be conflict or cooperation between multinationals and host and home governments. This course focuses on the ever-changing relations between multinationals and national governments from the late 19th century to the present.

column1: International business takes place in a broader societal context with local and global stakeholders who demand responsible business conduct wherever firms operate. In addition, calls have recently become louder for internationally operating firms to take on grand challenges (such as the UN Sustainable Development Goals) and play their part in making the world more equal, as well as environmentally and socially more sustainable. This course unfolds the societal and environmental dimensions of international business, offering students tools to conceptualize and manage the complex set of relationships between firms, their stakeholders, and society at large.

column1: ​Understanding the financial perspective on international business operations can unlock rich insights into business models, economic developments, and political decisions. While changes in currency values or interest rates appear to be abstract topics to most people, these developments have far-reaching implications for corporations and the potential to radically alter the business landscape of a country.

The course International Corporate Finance provides participants with the knowledge to understand the financial perspective of a firm that operates internationally. The goal of the course is to understand how firms are affected by international financial markets, how firms can manage risks from international operations, and how changes in financial markets are related to the development of an economy. These aspects are not only relevant for the finance department of a company, but also impact the strategic decision making of a firm, marketing strategies, and the supplier-side of a firm. As currencies constitute a major risk factor and information source for international operations and developments, this topic will receive special attention. By the end of the course, participants are able to apply finance theory to gain a deeper understanding of daily business news and global economic developments.

The course is highly interactive and employs a variety of didactic formats, including lectures, case studies, in-class exercises, and group presentations. As the focus of the course is on the application of finance theory, the course is suitable for participants with or without a strong background in finance. Participants without a finance background can find recommended online resources in the course manual to review basic financial concepts such discounting and time-value of money, as well as basic features of financial securities (stocks, bonds, and options).
Additional information about this course is available in the video Welcome to International Corporate Finance.

column1: This course will examine international dispute settlement in more depth, and with emphasis on inter-state judicial institutions, such as the International Court of Justice, and state/on-state dispute settlement. The opening lectures will address themes such as the concept of “international dispute”, the obligation to resolve disputes peacefully, the matrix of available dispute settlement options and the role and specificity of judicial dispute settlement mechanisms. Subsequent lectures will be devoted to the norms of “international legal procedure” governing international tribunals, with a focus on the International Court of Justice. The remaining lectures will turn their attention to the examination of specific judicial institutions, cross-cutting issues such as the independence and selection of judges and arbitrators, the role of the current dispute settlement “architecture”. Specific institutions which will be discussed include ITLOS, the WTO DS system and other mixed dispute settlement bodies, such as ICSID.

column1: Why are some rich, while others remain poor? How have international trade, states, institutions, and (human) capital flows affected economic growth? These are some of the key questions that economic history deals with. Since 1500 the world has seen a wide variety of economic developments, such as industrialization, imperialism and colonialism, waves of globalization and deglobalization, and the rise and fall of economic centers. Transportation and communication technologies have created a smaller world with a higher level of economic interdependence.

These developments have had profound impacts on the economic development of regions around the world. Apart from war and treaties, the field of international relations also includes this economic dimension through trade, investment and other monetary relations. This course focuses on international trade and the development of international monetary systems. Furthermore, economic policies have varied over time, ranging from mercantilist power politics to international economic collaboration and from free trade to protectionism. This course addresses the questions that underpin global economic history and introduces theories from the field of international relations, including Realism, Liberalism, Constructivism, English School, Marxism, and Neoliberal Institutionalism.

column1: International economics deals with issues raised by the interactions between countries. It can be divided into two broad fields: international trade and open-economy macroeconomics. The first deals with the real side of international economic relations, i.e. the exchange of goods and services, and answers questions like: Why do countries trade? What do they trade? What are the consequences of trade? How is it regulated by policy? The second deals with the monetary side of the international economy, i.e. the exchange of assets, and focuses in particular on how the exchange rate between two currencies is determined.

Although macroeconomic quantities are at the core of the analysis, a microeconomic perspective is also often employed. Furthermore, the nature of the subject implies that international economists frequently find inspiration elsewhere for their applications, for example from geography, econometrics, development economics, monetary economics, industrial organisation, etc. This approach results in a rich diversity of insights, nonetheless characterised by a remarkable coherence.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing this course, the students will:

column2: • understand the benefits and costs of international trade;
• be familiar with alternative theoretical models for explaining international trade;
• understand the relationships between exchange rates, interest rates and price levels.

column1: The course international economics focuses primarily on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international trade, capital flows, economic growth, exchange rates and financial crises. Although macroeconomic quantities are at the core of the analysis, these will usually be built up from a microeconomics perspective. The nature of the analysis implies that international economists frequently find inspiration elsewhere for their applications, for example from economic geography, monetary economics, econometrics, development economics or industrial organization. This approach results in a rich diversity of insights, nonetheless characterized by a remarkable coherence.

column1: Instructors: Prof. F.J.G.M. Klaassen (UvA), Dr J. Emami Namini (EUR) and Prof. M. Bosker (EUR)

International interdependencies have long been important for economic policy, and globalization has further strengthened that relevance. This holds not only for small open economies, such as the Netherlands, but also for Europe and worldwide. This course provides basic insights based on micro foundations to better understand such interdependencies, both from a theoretical and empirical viewpoint. The course covers international trade as well as international finance.

The international trade part starts with a discussion of modern quantitative trade models, focusing on their implication for welfare in different countries as well as that of heterogeneous firms within a country. The last session then focusses on how to assess the models’ welfare implications in the data. We discuss influential empirical papers that study not only the aggregate welfare effects of trade, but that also highlight the importance of considering the distributional consequences of trade

The international finance part of the course starts from the view of the current account as a vehicle for intertemporal trade, driven by optimizing behavior of agents, which helps to analyze topics such as global imbalances and sustainability of foreign debt. We also discuss interest rate parities, floating nominal exchange rates, speculative attacks on fixed rates, sticky prices and exchange rate
volatility, quantifying pressure on the forex market for any exchange rate regime, and the relevance of exchange market pressure for central bank policy.
Students also have to write a short academic essay in which they apply a theory to a real-life event, for example.

column1: <body>International environmental law (IEL) is an innovative, dynamic, and rapidly developing field that seeks to ameliorate global environmental issues such as the impacts of climate change and marine pollution/exploitation. As the causes, effects, and potential solutions of such global phenomena transcend national boundaries, international cooperation is increasingly important as reflected in a growing number of international environmental agreements governing disparate issues such as nuclear testing, hazardous substances, and atmospheric pollution. This course aims to provide students with an overview of the evolution of international environmental law, as well as an introduction to the major concepts, cases, and principles that shape effective global environmental governance. Throughout the course, attention will be focused on international responses to environmental issues with a transboundary or global scope. Following the introductory lectures, which will set the scene by introducing the major players (international institutions and actors) in the field, students will have an opportunity to explore the role of international law in regulating environmental problems such as marine pollution, climate change, nuclear testing, as well as the governance of outer space, the Arctic, and Antarctica.</body>

column1: Since the end of World War II, the international investments and other foreign activities of companies and individuals have grown substantially, and this growth is accelerating in recent decades. Firms of all types and sizes now face decisions about how to best obtain and allocate resources abroad. At the same time, significant differences in economic development between countries have persisted, and these give rise to considerable variation in the prevalence of market imperfections. Consequently, basic financial decisions now involve cross-border complexities.

This course shows how macro-level forces of trade, investment, and finance result from and, conversely, affect the micro-level actions of firms and households. In examining the key issues in international finance, we will focus on recent developments and incorporate theoretical, empirical, policy, and institutional dimensions.

The course begins with introduction describing the key trends and developments of the global economy and financial markets in the recent decades and discussing three main benefits of financial globalization: efficient investment, international risk sharing, and discipline effect on macroeconomic or corporate policies. We will discuss also one major cost of financial globalization, the sovereign debt and default.
The rest of the course is split into the two main parts: International investments and International business.

The topics covered in the International investments part include equity asset pricing in international context, foreign exchange returns, currency markets, and currency risk, international investment anomalies, and issues related international diversification of investment risk (or international risk sharing).

In the second part, we will touch upon selected issues related to the international activities at the micro (firm) level. This includes basic theory and key stylized facts about the multinational companies and selected issues related to practical international investing and international operations by the firms.
We try to arrange a guest lecture covering the practical aspects of the lecture material.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Understand and explain key theoretical principles explaining the interrelationships between economies in the globalized world. Understand and interpret macroeconomic concepts in the context of a globalized economy.
• Understand of the mechanisms that determine the evolution of the global economic environment and its influence on domestic financial markets.
• Learn the theory of how financial globalization affect pricing of internationally traded equity assets. Reconcile the empirical evidence with the theoretical predictions of the models.
• Describe the behavior of foreign exchange returns, putting them in the theoretical framework introduced in the lecture on global asset pricing.
• Learn the patterns in the data and theories explaining the international capital flows and the international investment anomalies.
• Get familiar with the scholarly and policy debate about the benefits and costs of financial globalization.

• Understand the reasons for emergence and examine the role of multinational firms. Learn about decisions, risks, and practical issues facing companies participating in international markets. Analyze and discuss financial problems corporations face that result from operating in an international environment.
• Read and critically evaluate academic and policy papers related to international finance.
• Interpret the key economic news in the context of theory and empirical research covered in the course.
• Obtain, analyze, present, and interpret the relevant economic and financial data.
• Learn to apply the econometric techniques for empirical tests of the key relationships related to international finance.

column1: This course provides an overview of the key issues in financial reporting. We use International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and relate the requirements for each particular topic to the underlying concepts and principles. Topics are discussed at the backdrop of the conceptual issues and the contemporary views that inform the debate. Using examples from practice and contrasting different views on how certain issues should affect the financial statements, the course contributes to a profound understanding and critical attitude towards financial reporting standards. This will help you learn to make informed judgements and think critically about financial reporting problems. These are necessary skills for your future career, whether you will be preparing, auditing or using financial statements compliant with IFRS.
​The course starts with a short refresher of basic of the Conceptual Framework. We will continue with more advanced areas, for example:

column2: • Fair value measurement
• Financial instruments
• Business combinations and goodwill impairment testing
• Pensions and share-based payments
• Revenue recognition

column1: In this course we will reason about financial reporting primarily in a forward direction, i.e. analyse a fact pattern and decide how the facts shall be reflected in the financial statements.

column1: On completion of this course, students will be familiar with:

column2: • The international institutional setting and regulatory landscape of financial reporting;
• The objective of financial reporting and the main concepts from a theoretical perspective and as set out in the Conceptual Framework;
• The structure and style of accounting standards and the debate in key problem areas (for example as evidenced in de Basis for Conclusions);
• The main requirements concerning recognition and measurement for the selected topics and the related IAS/IFRS.

column1: Students should then be able to:

column2: • Understand and discuss the main provisions and criteria of the accounting standards covered in this course;
• Use underlying principles and concepts to critically evaluate financial reporting decisions;
• Make informed judgements for financial reporting issues in the problem areas that are covered in this course;
• Compile financial statement items from fact patterns compliant with the standards covered in this course.
• Critically evaluate the current state and challenges of international financial reporting and discuss various (theoretical) perspectives that inform the debate.

column1: <body>This course focuses on the impact of international treaty law on regulating health care systems. Therefore, this course starts with identifying the underlying principles of health law. These principles explain the ratio of regulatory intervention in health care, i.e. good health. Good health raises questions about access to medical care, human rights and health care, scarcity of resources, mobility of patients, health professionals and medical products, and market competition in health care. To a large extent these questions are influenced by legal standards as defined by international treaty law.</body>

column1: The course adopts a holistic approach to learning international human rights law, beginning from its normative foundations and emergence as a distinct field of international law to its contemporary status and challenges for the future. Given the introductory nature of this course, emphasis is placed throughout on idealism as well as realism, including an understanding of how international and domestic politics have influenced and continue to influence the field of international human rights law. On the normative side, participants will analyses the merits and demerits of categorizing human rights under different labels and its effects on human rights promotion. They will look at case studies from around the world that expose the tensions between cultural relativism and universality of human rights, and will also look at the concepts of collective rights and rights of vulnerable persons. On the practical side, participants will be introduced to the most important mechanisms as well as challenges to the realisation and promotion of human rights, including State compliance and judicial enforcement. Finally, the inter-play between nation-states and civil society will be scrutinised with a strong focus on NGO activism and the emerging challenges thereto.

Practices of journalism vary considerably, depending on the wider - local, national and even transnational (Al Jazeera, CNN) - contexts in which they take place. Departing from some of the main benchmarks in (Western) journalism with regard to training, routines, formats, organization, ethics and culture, this course familiarizes students with the field of journalism studies from the perspective of foreign correspondence and their journalistic practices across the globe. This entails gaining insight in the obstacles correspondents meet when working in non-democratic, non-free environments. This course combines theory, research and practice related to foreign correspondence. Students learn about the concrete work experiences from correspondents themselves, they learn to reflect on these experiences from an academic perspective and to relate their learned insights to international journalism in general.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: This course is about laws and regulations that are in use to tackle transnational social problems. One can think of human rights issues, international trade barriers, global environmental problems such as climate change, and work-related problems emanating from global production chains such as exploitation and unhealthy and unsafe working conditions.

Laws can be conceived as a specific kind of rules; whereas laws are legally binding, regulation also encompasses legally non-binding rules. What does it actually mean to say that laws are legally binding? It means, first, that judges are bound to the application and interpretation of existing law when judging. It also means that, in order to be recognized, during the making of these formal laws several procedures must have been followed. For instance, laws can only be enacted when they are based on authority of governments or parliaments, they must be approved by parliaments and senates, and they must be announced in a way that actors can respond to the proposed new law, etc. Most laws are about formulating and interpreting social norms. As such they contribute to creating and upholding social order. The law is such an important means of normative ordering in modern society because it is backed-up by the monopoly of the state to use violence. Hence, the law and the state are inextricably linked. During a long historical process, constitutions have been developed that formalize the relationship between law and the state. In democratic societies, this has led to a situation wherein the monopoly of the state to enact and enforce laws is based on the principle of the ‘rule of law’ and limited by the respect of human rights.

At the domestic level, the law pertains to the rights and duties that individuals have viz a viz each other as well as those between states and individuals. The rules regulating contacts within the society of states are generally called international law. One of the aims of international law is to address cross border societal problems in a peaceful way. Traditionally international law is based on national sovereignty which means that there is no authority above states. However, over time states have empowered non-state actors with supranational (or intergovernmental) authorities such as the international organizations that are part of the UN family. This development has fundamentally changed international law as it means that states have surrendered some of their sovereignty to these international organizations. Consequently, modern international law can be characterized by the co-existence of a horizontal regime that is based on the relations between sovereign nations and a vertical regime wherein states accept some authority by central international organizations.

The first part of this course deals with the basics of law in modern society. It addresses questions such as: what is law, where can it be found, how is it organized into different domains, and how does it relate to the state? It also shows the development and evolution of traditional international law. But, supranational or intergovernmental law, with their many regulations and institutions, what do these concepts actually refer to? And what does it imply when sovereign states empower non-state actors at the international level and when also non-state actors that have not been empowered by states get involved in international law? Why is international environmental law particularly illustrative of the main characteristics of international law in current era?

The second part of the course is about regulation. In current society, a major part of all the existing rules are not directly legally binding in the way laws are. Think of the internal rules and working procedures of governmental departments or international organizations, contractual clauses between firms, voluntary codes of conduct of businesses and private standards of certifying bodies. In fact, in the last decades, the role of these legally non-binding rules has increased spectacularly. States have delegated regulatory tasks and responsibilities and both profit and non-profit private organizations have assumed them. These developments have been spurred on by a globalizing market economy that generates all kinds of transboundary social problems, such as climate change, child labor and exploitation. The private regulation of global markets interacts with domestic and international law at different levels and in different ways.

To the end of the course, the focus shifts from the normative ordering with formal (public) law towards ordering with (private) regulation. How has regulation evolved in the last few decades in terms of actors, instruments and goals? What theoretical perspectives can be distinguished on understanding these recent trends in regulation? Can private international regulation fill the global governance gap that is left by law as is sometimes assumed in the literature? If not, how do law and regulation interact?

The conceptual focus of law and regulation is illustrated with the handling of cross-national social problems, spurred on by a globalizing economy. The first part of the course aims at answering corresponding questions with a comprehensive introduction in the study of (international) law. The second part of the course reflects on the changing role of (international) regulation in contemporary society. </body>

6. mention similarities and differences between the concepts of law and of regulation;
7. explain different perspectives on recent trends in regulation;
8. evaluate the assumption that private actors can close the global governance gap.

column1: Moot court is a simulation of a fictional dispute between countries before the International Courts. Students prepare oral and written pleadings arguing both the applicant and respondent positions of the case. The students analyze the problem, identify the legal issues, research the law, write the briefs and orally present in front of an international tribunal, like the real-life lawyers do.

A team of EUC students will participate in Telders International Law Moot Court Competition, which is organized by Leiden University. Each year student teams are presented with a case involving a fictitious dispute between two States, which is brought before the International Court of Justice (ICJ). It is up to the teams to defend the two States to the best of their abilities.

In Telders International Law Moot Court Competition the students' written and oral argumentations are judged by legal experts such as judges from the ICJ(Telders' Final in the Peace Palace), other international courts, delegates from the International Committee of the Red Cross and professors of law guaranteeing high intellectual standards and the prestige of these Competitions. Therefore, participation in these Moot Courts is a strong asset especially for the students who wish to do a Masters Degree in International Law.

Throughout four quads, weekly meetings will be held (contact hours 2-3 hours per week), readings will be assigned, and student preparation is expected at individual and group level. The students will be closely supervised by the coaches. The deadlines for the assessments will be known provided once the competition cases and timelines will bear published. Please keep in mind that these deadlines might fall within the Winter Break, which could mean that some work would be required during the breaks.

column1: <body>This course gives a basic introduction of international migration and various related phenomena. The course focuses on the causes of international migration and the consequences of international migration in both sending and receiving countries. We will extensively discuss economic and sociological theories that try to explain why people migrate from one country to another, and often from one part of the world to another. A second major issue in the course is the consequences of migration for sending countries and communities. Does migration contribute to economic and social development in sending communities? And what are the consequences for receiving countries, in terms of both the socio-economic (or ‘structural’) integration of migrants and the socio-cultural integration (or ‘assimilation’) of migrants or a lack of assimilation and resulting cultural diversity in receiving countries and communities where many migrants settle?</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Have insight in the size and character of international migration processes in various parts of the world, both in the present and in the past
• Have a solid understanding of economic and sociological theories about factors that contribute to the rise and continuation of processes of international migration
• Understand to what extent and how migration policies and migration control of receiving countries are able to steer international migration flows

• Understand and will be able to take a substantiated position about whether or not, or under which conditions, international migration contributes to the economic development of and social relations within sending communities
• Understand and are able to take a substantiated position about whether or not, or under what conditions, migrants can incorporate in receiving countries
• Are able to develop and formulate policy options and recommendations with regards to current issues related to international migration and immigrant integration.

column1: <body>Dit vak verschaft een inleiding in internationale migratie en diverse gerelateerde verschijnselen. Het vak belicht zowel de oorzaken van internationale migratie als de gevolgen van internationale migratie voor de zendende en de ontvangende samenlevingen. We bespreken diverse economische en sociologische theorieën die verklaren waarom mensen vanuit het ene naar een ander land migreren, vaak van het ene naar een ander deel van de wereld. Een tweede centraal thema in het vak betreft de gevolgen van migratie voor de herkomstlanden en –gemeenschappen. Wat zijn economische en sociale ontwikkelingen in de herkomstgemeenschappen als gevolg van migratie? En wat zijn de gevolgen voor de ontvangende samenlevingen op het gebied van sociaaleconomische (of structurele) integratie en sociaal-culturele integratie (of “assimilatie”). Hoe kan de sterke culturele diversiteit in de gemeenschappen waar veel migranten zich vestigen begrepen worden? En hoe reageren de oorspronkelijke bewoners van deze gemeenschappen hierop? Al dit soort vragen staan centraal in dit vak.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Na afronding van dit vak heeft de student:

column2: • Inzicht in de omvang en het karakter van internationale migratieprocessen in verschillende delen van de wereld, zowel in het heden als het verleden;
• Goed begrip van economische en sociologische theorieën die bijdragen aan de opkomst, continuering en eventueel afname van internationale migratieprocessen;
• Begrijpen in welke mate en hoe migratiebeleid en migratie controle van ontvangende samenlevingen internationale migratiestromen kunnen sturen;

• Begrijpen en een onderbouwd standpunt kunnen innemen of internationale migratie al dan niet, en onder welke voorwaarden, bijdraagt aan de economische ontwikkeling van en sociale verhoudingen in herkomstgemeenschappen;
• Begrijpen en een onderbouwd standpunt kunnen innemen of migranten (eerste en tweede generatie) al dan niet, en onder welke voorwaarden, een plek vinden in de ontvangende samenleving;
• Beleidsopties en -aanbevelingen kunnen ontwikkelen en formuleren omtrent actuele thema’s gelieerd aan internationale migratie en de integratie van migranten.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Public International Organisations, including European Union, together form the structural web of co-operative relationships between states. They have also become elements of the modern state's institutional system and of its public administration. The law of public international organisation is the body of rules, principles and concepts governing the functioning of international organisations, their interrelationships and their legal connection with the (member) states' administrations

The precise nature of the European Union (EU) remains problematic for traditional explanations of international relations. The EU is neither a state nor an international organisation. This course investigates the politics and legal measures that determine the extent to which the EU is a global actor. These concepts are evaluated in a variety of international policy areas: trade/economic policy, development/humanitarian assistance policy, the Common Foreign and Security Policy, and Common Security and Defence policy. The course also explores the EUs varied relations with other major powers: the United States, Russia and China/Asia.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the basic legal and institutional structures governing the functioning of international organizations, and thereby grasp in structural terms, the international system of which modern states operate in;
• Understand the steps of European integration, as well as the constitutional and institutional foundations of European external relations;

• Develop a proficiency in recognizing EU’s competence, tools, policy choices and role in different strands of EU external action such as enlargement, association, neighbourhood, development, humanitarian aid, trade, common foreign and security policy; and the coordination thereof;
• Analyze EU relations with other international actors from a structural and legal framework.

column1: This course assesses historical developments in the global world economy with a particular emphasis on the role of international institutions such as the WTO, the IMF and the World Bank. It applies political economy theories to explain and evaluate the need for global cooperation in the areas of trade, finance, poverty reduction and the environment. It deals with the internal governance structure of global economic institutions as well as their effectiveness. The course explicitly includes the perspectives of developing countries, both in discussing the consequences of economic globalization and in discussing the effectiveness of international economic institutions and regimes. In addition, the effectiveness of foreign aid is discussed.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Assess the nature of economic globalization and its consequences, in particular for developing countries
• Evaluate the need for global public goods in the areas of trade, finance, poverty and the environment
• Evaluate the decision making procedures of the major existing global economic institutions and regimes, such as the WTO, the IMF, the World Bank and the (UN) Framework Convention on Climate Change
• Assess the effectiveness of these global economic institutions both in general and for developing countries in particular
• Evaluate foreign aid approaches
• Analyze data from international databases to answer simple but relevant empirical questions.

column1: The state and the market have been key organising principles of social order since the rise of capitalism as the dominant political-economic system in the fifteenth century. This course analyses the complex and dynamic relationships between state and market against the background of geopolitical and historical change. On the basis of an understanding of state-market relationships as historically contingent aspects operating as part of a wider international political economy, the course investigates the diverse manifestations of state and market under capitalist order. The course focuses on the evolution of the state-market interaction by addressing topics such as the rise of the Company State and mercantilism, the fiscal-military state, imperialism, forms of development, varieties of capitalism in the post-World War II era, and the rise of neoliberalism.

column2: <title></title>

column1: 1.       Students will be able to analyse the development of key institutions of international political economy since 1500;
2.       Students will be able to evaluate the historically contingent relationship between state, market and capital;
3.       Students will be able to compare and contrast different ideas on international political economy;
4.       Students will be able to compose a blog post about contemporary world politics using historical and theoretical insights.

This course will be significantly different than any other course you have ever taken. Its design is such that it has features of both a course and a competitive consulting assignment. The elective covers many aspects of branding, marketing and communications in a challenging way. We focus on digital & data, corporate social responsibility & purpose and neuromarketing.
L’Oréal is offering the marketing students of Erasmus University a unique opportunity to play the role of consultant, and dive into a very dynamic, real-life, practical assignment.
At the same time, the selective is designed such that teams will be able to build inspiring and well-underpinned brand experiences by applying the right concepts, methods and techniques.

It provides the opportunity to develop marketing and consulting skills through a practical, real-life experience, the chance to work closely with professionals in their field, and the possibility of winning a contest at one of several levels. All of these can contribute to one’s clarification of what kind of professional career could be interesting to pursue (or not) in the future. Being able to discuss the experience and what was learned with future employers. The course as it is designed, is a lot of work, and a lot of fun to apply marketing and strategy models and techniques learned during their study in a real-life business situation.

column1: In the past decades governments all over the world, including at the international level, have been involved in various waves of reform of the public sector and organizations therein. Different labels are  in use to describe these reforms, such as New Public Management, New Public Governance, and Whole of Governance. In this course you will become acquainted with these reforms in different countries, their trajectory and results. Examples will come from organizational reforms such as the large scale creation of semi-autonomous agencies, to reforms of financial and HR management.

The impact of these reforms and the financial crisis on the public sector in various countries is highly disputed. Some authors claim there is a trend towards convergence, making all public sectors become alike, while other authors point to the trade-offs and paradoxes between the strive for more efficiency and quality at the same time. Precise results are difficult to ascertain because of a lack of evaluation studies but it is clear that not all reforms have been beneficial.
In this course students will also investigate an example of a reform in a country outside of the Netherlands, to explain the causes and consequences of that reform.

This course is part of the Master in International Public Management and Public Policy (IMP) and also available as an elective course for students from other Master programmes in Public Administration. Please notice that the eligibility criteria for the IMP programme are higher than for the Dutch Master programmes, both in terms of English proficiency (which is higher than the level achieved in Dutch secondary schools) and in terms of grades obtained in the Bachelor programme. This course is geared towards this higher level. Students from other programmes are strongly recommended to take note of these admission criteria for the IMP Master, see www.imp.eur.nl

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After following  this course students will be able to:

column2: • Describe the most important public management reforms in various countries and some international organizations that have taken place in the past decades;
• Explain the origins of these reforms and the different reform trajectories that have occurred in different countries;
• Analyse, evaluate and reflect on the results or impact of public management reforms in various countries, including unintended consequences, trade-offs and paradoxes that have occurred.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The minor will explore how governments, non-governmental organisations and international institutions interact in their efforts to protect human rights.

State sovereignty and international relations have a profound impact on the ability of the international community to respond to gross human rights violations. Thus, in this course, the positive and negative impacts of domestic politics and transnational actors and the collision of human rights ideals with the doctrine of state sovereignty will be recurring themes. Instruments of statecraft ranging from diplomacy, monitoring and mediation to peacekeeping and humanitarian military intervention are depicted and analyzed in the light of case studies.

The course will examine unresolved practical, theoretical (and maybe philosophical) issues and questions concerning the universality of human rights; whose responsibility it is to protect human rights; and whether human rights conventions, laws, and regimes are effective. Thus, the course looks at the juxtaposition of the traditional claims of states to guard sovereignty and impose order against more recent claims by individuals to freedom, rights, justice, universal moral order and humane treatment.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: 1)      Understanding the theories and issues of International Relations
2)      Understanding foundational values and basic doctrines of fundamental rights, being able to apply the latter in concrete cases

3)      Understanding the interaction between sovereignty concerns for states with ‘legitimacy concerns’ of international courts, and being able to identify the tension with the effective protection of fundamental rights.
4)      Understanding the role of interpretation principles characteristic of human rights in this regard.

column2: </body>

column1: This course provides a critical introduction to International Relations (IR) Theory for historians. It seeks to develop the analytical tools required for theoretically informed historical research into IR. We will begin with two crucial philosophical (epistemological and ontological) questions: what is, or should be, the relationship between History and IR Theory? What ‘is’ theory, and what does it ‘do’ for us as researchers? The module will approach important current IR theories including postcolonialism, realism, Marxism and liberalism. IR theory will be applied to the modern history of the Middle East and North Africa, including that of diaspora’s rooted in these areas. A brief introduction of the modern history of these regions is included. Cases range from United Nations interventions, of which there are many, to institutions like the European Song Festival, Turkey and Israel being part of that contest. Also the current crisis in the area, resulting in the arrival of large numbers of refugees in Europe will be considered in the context of IR.

• Students can apply IR theories to the modern history of the Middle East and North Africa

column1: The aim of this introductory course on international relations theory is to familiarise you with the concepts, ideas and analytical tools necessary to understand state behaviour and relationships between various actors in the international system. Competing analytical perspectives explaining state behaviour such as realism, liberalism and constructivism will be examined. The course will also examine alternative approaches to international relations such as Marxism, feminism, post-colonialism, post-structuralism, and Green theory. Each of these frameworks will be applied to different case studies to explore how the theory works in practice. By the end of the course you will have knowledge of international relations theory and are able to analyse a myriad of issues in global affairs from a variety of perspectives.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Students will understand how major scholars have theorized international relations; assess contributions and short-comings of both mainstream and alternative theories; enhance their analytical skills and develop capacity to engage in complex political issues; demonstrate how theory provides a road map by which to examine international events and processes.</body>

column1: Why do countries trade? Is everyone better off from trade? Why and how do governments use trade policy instruments and how do they affect the economy? What is the role of the WTO and what can explain the proliferation of trade agreements? These are some of the questions we will explore in this course. We will begin by reviewing the traditional trade models of Ricardo and Hecksher-Ohlin, and identify the winners and losers from trade. Then we will study the instruments of trade policy and their effects. The course will then move to the political economy of trade policy to understand what determines trade policy, and we will conclude by studying the world trading system, paying special attention to the role of the WTO and regional trade agreements.
The following topics will be covered during this course:
1. Introduction to Trade and Trade Policy
4. Trade Policy Instruments and their effects
6. Multilateral Trade Negotiations and the Rise of FTAs

• To acquire mathematical skills in formalizing economic models.

column1: The International Business Project (or IBP) constitutes an important (and mandatory) part of the Spring semester within the CEMS programme at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University (RSM). Over a period of approximately four months, you will work intensively on a consultancy project together with three/four other students, carried out for a company or institution. Both a university and a company coach supervise the project. The general aim of the project is to respond professionally and effectively to a real-world management problem and to learn from working together in multidisciplinary and culturally heterogeneous groups.

Most students will already be familiar with various business disciplines through course work; however, the interdisciplinary use of this knowledge and the capacity to translate it into practical solutions is often a new challenge. The business project permits students to combine theory and practice – they learn how to formulate a project proposal and relevant research questions, analyse problems, develop recommendations and propose solutions to the problem. In addition to providing hands-on experience on how to deal with a business problem, the course also offers a unique chance to learn about how teams function and to learn how to work effectively in teams. Therefore, the project incorporates leadership sessions that challenge students to deepen their understanding of the process of working in multidisciplinary and international teams.

</style>

• To learn more about project management: how to run projects, how to plan and organise activities, meetings, and processes

• To learn more about managing team processes and your own individual role within a team: how to work in multidisciplinary, international team settings, how to take up initiative and leadership roles, how to contribute to the most effective team performance

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: One manifestation of our globalizing world is the emergence of innovative start-ups that have a worldwide focus and sometimes resource base from inception. The international activities of these firms that have decided to go abroad almost directly after their creation, have received an increasing amount of attention over the past years; they are called born globals or international new ventures. In addition to small and medium-sized firms with incremental growth strategies, the focus in this course is on these dynamic start-up firms that make products and sell services that are ‘new to the world’, strive for scaling up their activities and seek international presence. These growth-oriented start-ups with global expansion strategies face a lot of uncertainty compared to established multinational companies with more traditional products and services: their novel products or services are unknown to the market, so is the effect of the product for the customer. Also, in bringing these niche products and services to the international market, young firms have limited resources and few complementary assets (they do not have deep pockets and needed additional start-up and growth financing).

In this course we will look how innovative start-ups and ambitious small firms mitigate the risks of starting-up, early growth and internationalization, and more specifically how they address and manage their country selection and market investigation choice(s), their entry mode strategies and international operations and capabilities. Other interesting characteristics of these international new ventures are the importance of the founders and the entrepreneurial team, their particular motives for international expansion, and the relevance of strategic partners and investors.

Increasingly entrepreneurship is seen as a promising approach aiming to solve complex social, environmental, and economic problems with innovative solutions. Here we deal with the overlaps between collaborative entrepreneurship, sustainable development and social venturing. This entrepreneurial collaboration may manifest itself through cross-actor participation within entrepreneurial processes, addressing sustainability issues by developing entrepreneurial solutions, and society-wide cooperation between different forms of entrepreneurship such as social entrepreneurship, sustainable entrepreneurship, and institutional entrepreneurship. Compared with commercial and independent entrepreneurship, social and collaborative entrepreneurship is characterized by the process of pursuing opportunities in pursuit of high social returns (cf. market leadership, or profit maximization). Instead of establishing a new venture to seize and commercialize opportunities, the social entrepreneur recognizes a social problem and uses entrepreneurial principles to organize, create, and manage a venture to make social change possible or realize a societal goal (e.g. the slow take-off of recycle stores in the Netherlands).

This Master course is for students who plan to become involved in new ventures and fast-growing and internationalizing firms, or high-impact social ventures in the near future (i.e. immediately after graduating) or at mid-career. Another reason to take this course is that some simply want to more as a future consultant to young companies or entrepreneurship support manager about the key entrepreneurial and managerial processes found in start-ups and fast-growing companies

column1: At the end of the course, students should be able to:

column2: • Know and evaluate the leading theories, concepts and models in (international) entrepreneurship and social/sustainable entrepreneurship
• Understand distinctive characteristics of the start-up, growth and internationalization of small/young firms

• Recognize the opportunities and risks offered by different institutional settings of nations or regions and to understand their relevance for and influence on the starting and growing of young/small firms;
• Compare and evaluate (dis)advantages of different internationalization strategies and entry modes

• Identify key entrepreneurial activities (e.g. opportunity identification, new venture planning, bootstrapping, etc.) and explain the key role of entrepreneurial initiatives in creating new organizations and building economic activity

• Understand the difference between commercial and social/sustainable entrepreneurship and comprehend the latter’s contribution to bringing about societal change and realizing the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
• Develop a pro-active and entrepreneurial mind-set (of the individual student)
• Initiate and complete teamwork under time pressure
• Develop and show effective presentation and writing skills and create high-quality deliverables

column1: This course provides an overview about the determinants as well as outcomes of internationalization decisions that organizations (MNEs and SMEs) make in order to compete and operate in world markets. The course has a theoretical component as well as a practical one, and these components are closely intertwined. During the course, we will work with an existing organization to solve their (real-life) internationalization problem. This case will be used throughout the module and students will develop a “global strategy” for this organization. At the end of the course, a presentation will be held to its board of directors in which you and your team will recommend a strategy about its international expansion. Consequently, we will work on ‘big’ make or break decisions for organizations when they internationalize. At the highest level of the firm, leaders deal with complexity, ambiguity and uncertainty. You will too. The course discusses topics and frameworks that will help you navigate through these difficulties. Understanding them will enable you to pursue international (strategic) developments in the future. The development of a “Global Strategy” concerns high-level executive or general managers who must use a perspective that is qualitatively different from that of the lower-level functional managers.
This course’s lectures will be offered as a combination of:

column2: • Synchronous online sessions
• Asynchronous online sessions
• And some on-campus, face-to-face sessions

column1: The objective of this course is to develop students’ understanding of how international operations differ from domestic ones. It provides students with the necessary knowledge for a career or further study in international business.
We will focus on four outcomes. At the end of this course students should be able to:

column2: <li>
Integrate both theory and practice to address international strategy cases.
<li>
Defend a choice relevant to international strategy of MNEs (e.g., location choice or entry mode) using a theory (or framework).
<li>
Distinguish between the three, leading international strategy perspectives and be able to identify the strengths and weakness of each.
<li>
(In groups) Analyze and develop/create an international strategy for an existing business to show their understanding of core international strategy concepts.
