column1: Deze module is een onderdeel van Blok 6. Onder dit blok vallen ook de modules GW206AVV en GW206I.
Deze module staat enkel open voor studenten Gezondheidswetenschappen, BMG.

In Nederland wordt, net als in verschillende andere landen, bij de organisatie van gezondheidszorg gebruik gemaakt van marktprikkels. Dit betekent dat voor de afstemming van vraag en aanbod van zorg niet wordt vertrouwd op gedetailleerde aanbod- en prijsregulering door de overheid. In plaats daarvan speelt onderlinge concurrentie een belangrijke rol. Zorgaanbieders hebben aanzienlijke vrijheden gekregen en dienen nu veel meer dan in het verleden te wedijveren om de gunst van patiënten en zorgverzekeraars. Veel prijzen zijn niet langer vooraf vastgesteld, maar onderhandelbaar tussen zorgaanbieders en zorginkopers zoals verzekeraars (curatieve zorg), gemeenten (jeugdzorg en maatschappelijke ondersteuning) en zorgkantoren (langdurige zorg). Voor zorgaanbieders zijn hun inkomsten niet langer gegarandeerd in de vorm van vaste budgetten, maar prestatieafhankelijk geworden.

Deze marktwerking vormt natuurlijk geen doel op zich. Het is een middel om te komen tot betere zorg tegen de juiste prijs. Dit is echter geen vanzelfsprekendheid, want de zorg is geen gewone markt. De gezondheidszorg heeft veel specifieke kenmerken die maken dat wat economen ‘de onzichtbare hand van de markt’ noemen hier zeker niet tot optimale uitkomsten leidt.

Om de publieke doelen op het gebied van kwaliteit, toegankelijkheid en betaalbaarheid te waarborgen is er daarom volop reden voor overheidsingrijpen in de gezondheidszorg. Helaas geldt dat strakke regulering van de gezondheidszorg geen wondermiddel is. Dit leidt tot de cruciale vraag welke rol is weggelegd voor de markt en welke rol de overheid moet spelen. Een eenvoudig en eenduidig antwoord op deze vraag is niet te geven. Ook al niet omdat de gewenste marktordening in de gezondheidszorg mede bepaald wordt door tijd- en plaatsgebonden maatschappelijke opvattingen over solidariteit, keuzevrijheid, welvaart en gezondheid. Er is dus sprake van een complexe zoektocht naar de juiste balans tussen marktwerking en overheidsingrijpen.

In de kennismodule leer je verschillende marktordeningsvraagstukken in de context van het huidige Nederlandse zorgstelsel vanuit zowel een algemeen en bedrijfseconomisch als juridisch perspectief te analyseren. Ook leer je evalueren in hoeverre concrete beleidsbeslissingen, gedrag van zorginkopers en zorgaanbieders, wet- & regelgeving en jurisprudentie wel of niet bijdragen aan een beter functioneren van markten in de gezondheidszorg.

column1: Deze module is een onderdeel van Blok 7. Onder dit blok vallen ook de modules GW207AVV en GW207I.
Deze module staat enkel open voor studenten Gezondheidswetenschappen, BMG.

De levensverwachting is de afgelopen decennia sterk toegenomen en daarmee het aandeel van ouderen in de bevolking. Iedereen weet dat ouderdom met gebreken komt, maar welke gebreken zijn dat? Maakt het daarbij uit of je man of vrouw bent? Hoeveel opleiding je hebt genoten? In welk land je ouders zijn geboren? Of hoe gezond je leeft? En wat betekent dit voor je behoefte aan zorg en ondersteuning? In het blok Zorgen voor Later kijken we - vanuit meerdere disciplines - naar de levensloop van mensen, hoe we zorg en ondersteuning zo goed mogelijk kunnen organiseren, en welke maatschappelijke gevolgen de vergrijzing heeft.

Veroudering leidt tot (gezondheids)problemen, waardoor mensen behoefte krijgen aan zorg. Ouderen hebben ook hulpbronnen die hen juist beschermen. Die helpen om verlies tegen te gaan en om kwetsbaarheid te voorkomen. We komen te weten wat het betekent om (gezond) ouder te worden: Welke problemen brengt ouder worden met zich mee? Hoe kun je hier mee omgaan en wat is daar tijdens iemands leven voor nodig? Zowel sociaal, fysiek, mentaal als financieel en qua zorg en ondersteuning? Je interviewt een oudere over zijn of haar levensloop om dit concreet te maken.

Ouderen met beperkingen en gezondheidsproblemen ontvangen van verschillende kanten hulp en zorg: uit hun sociale omgeving, van zorgorganisaties en van de overheid. Om die zorg goed te organiseren, moet je weten welke (veranderende) rol deze partijen hierbij spelen en wat het effect daarvan is. Hiervoor moet je kunnen beschrijven hoe de manier van organiseren (integraal, in netwerken, door interorganisationele samenwerking) van invloed is op de gezondheid en het welbevinden van mensen. Interventies van deze partijen kunnen het organiseren van zorg en ondersteuning aan ouderen vergemakkelijken of juist in de weg staan. Je verklaart welke rol de sociale omgeving, zorgorganisaties en de overheid spelen en analyseert het effect ervan.

Een behoorlijk groot deel van de zorg en ondersteuning wordt in Nederland collectief gefinancierd en georganiseerd. Tegelijkertijd is er meer nadruk op eigen verantwoordelijkheid: ouderen en hun omgeving moeten (mee)betalen voor zorg en die zorg zelf organiseren. Sommige ouderen hebben de financiële middelen, het opleidingsniveau en de mogelijkheden om dat te doen. Anderen kunnen dat om allerlei redenen niet. Technologische, demografische en andere ontwikkelingen binnen én buiten de gezondheidszorg betekenen vooruitgang op sommige vlakken maar leiden ook tot nieuwe dilemma’s. Je gebruikt een interdisciplinair denkkader om deze problemen in kaart te brengen en de beleidsimplicaties te formuleren.

Vanuit de sociaal-medische wetenschappen kijken we met een epidemiologische bril naar de gevolgen van de vergrijzing, zoals fysieke beperkingen, eenzaamheid en cognitieve veroudering en dementie. Vanuit de gezondheidspsychologie gaan we in op de vraag “Gezond ouder worden, hoe doe je dat?” En vanuit de medische sociologie proberen we te verklaren waarom er zoveel variatie is in de manier waarop mensen ouder worden en de gevolgen die dit heeft voor hun welbevinden.

Vanuit de organisatiewetenschappen krijg je inzicht in hoe je zorg zo kunt organiseren dat die past bij de behoeften van zorgvragers en ontwikkelingen in de maatschappij. Er is een toename aan complexe en meervoudige zorgvragen. Daarom leggen we een accent op innovatieve organisatievormen. Het integreren van het aanbod rondom de zorgvraag staat hierbij centraal. We gebruiken concepten uit de organisatiekunde en organisatiesociologie om te analyseren hoe nieuwe vormen van organiseren tot stand komen met aandacht voor het structuur- en actorperspectief. Ook bespreken we welke prestaties worden behaald met deze organisatievormen.

De hoeveelheid geld (en tijd) is beperkt en gezondheidszorg is duur. Gezondheid is bovendien een belangrijke bron van onzekerheid. Gezondheidseconomie biedt inzicht in hoe individuen, de overheid en andere organisaties keuzes maken hoe zij dat geld en die tijd het beste kunnen besteden en hoe zij die onzekerheid kunnen verminderen. Daarmee biedt het een denkkader om de oorzaken van verschillen in zorggebruik te beschrijven. Ook kun je hiermee op alle drie de niveaus keuzealternatieven formuleren en mogelijke consequenties evalueren.

column1: ‘Gemeenten schieten tekort bij hulp van personen met verward gedrag’, ‘Te lange wachtlijsten jeugdzorg bij ggz-instellingen’, ‘Decentralisatie heeft jeugd-ggz geen goed gedaan’, ‘Familie wil instanties aansprakelijk stellen voor dood autistische zoon’.

Als de jeugdzorg en geestelijke gezondheidszorg (ggz) in het nieuws komen, is dat vaak vanwege treurige gebeurtenissen of teleurstellende onderzoeksresultaten. Sinds 2015 zijn gemeenten verantwoordelijk voor jeugdzorg, inclusief ggz voor jongeren tot 18 jaar. Doel van deze decentralisatie was onder andere het bieden van maatwerk, een integrale aanpak en meer oog voor preventie. Maar de decentralisatie wordt juist vaak genoemd als oorzaak van nieuwe problemen. Ook de toename van het aantal ‘verwarde personen’ op straat, wordt vaak toegeschreven aan veranderingen in het overheidsbeleid: door te weinig plaats in ggz-instellingen, moeten mensen met geestelijke problematiek te snel aarden in ‘gewone’ buurten.

In dit blok kijken we naar de veranderingen in het sociale domein, met speciale aandacht voor jeugdzorg en ggz. We proberen te ontrafelen wat er nu eigenlijk aan de hand is. Zijn de problemen nieuw? Hoe kunnen we ze verklaren? Wat zijn mogelijke oplossingen? Maar ook: wat gaat er wel goed, welke succesvolle nieuwe initiatieven zijn er en doet Nederland het wel zo slecht, vanuit internationaal perspectief? We gebruiken kennis uit verschillende disciplines om deze maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen te begrijpen.
Jeugdzorg en ggz bieden interessante casussen die raken aan bredere maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen. We zien verschuivingen in de grenzen tussen:

column2: • Zorg en welzijn: Beleid en praktijk zijn tegenwoordig meer dan vroeger gericht op het brede welzijn van de cliënt. Het is niet alleen belangrijk om goede zorg te bieden. Er moet ook oog zijn voor andere domeinen, zoals huisvesting, onderwijs, arbeid en vrije tijd. Allemaal domeinen, waarmee mensen in het dagelijks leven hebben te maken en die elkaar overlappen. Toch werd (en wordt) op organisatieniveau niet altijd samengewerkt. Er wordt daarom vaak gepleit voor een meer integrale aanpak, waarbij allerlei organisaties en beleidsniveaus nauw met elkaar in contact staan.

• Formele en informele ondersteuning: Door de nadruk op welzijn, wordt het ook als ideaal gezien dat mensen zoveel mogelijk zorg en ondersteuning krijgen in hun eigen vertrouwde omgeving. En dat hun naasten (familie en buren) zoveel mogelijk die benodigde zorg en ondersteuning bieden. Ook moeten zorgbehoevenden in staat zijn tot ‘zelfmanagement’. Formele, professionele zorg moet vooral in dienst staan van het zelf-oplossend vermogen van zorgbehoevenden en hun informele netwerk.

• Nationale en lokale overheid: Goede zorg is gericht op het brede welzijn van de cliënt en wordt verleend in de eigen vertrouwde omgeving. Dat is momenteel de dominante overheidsvisie. Dit krijgt veelal invulling op gemeentelijk niveau. Het idee: gemeenten staan dichter bij de burger dan de centrale overheid en kunnen daarom meer maatwerk bieden. Maatwerk betekent echter ook dat er grotere verschillen tussen gemeenten kunnen ontstaan.

column1: Voor beleidsproblemen kunnen verschillende oplossingen bestaan die invloed hebben op burgers. Er kan bijvoorbeeld gekozen worden voor inzet van formele of informele hulp, een aanpak door nationale of lokale overheid en een focus op zorg of welzijn. Belangrijke vragen zijn: Hoe verhouden overheid en burger zich tot elkaar in het huidige beleid? Is dat anders dan in het verleden en in andere landen? Hoe kunnen we verschuivingen in beleidsideeën en -praktijken verklaren?

Er wordt tegenwoordig veel gesproken over de ‘participatiesamenleving’. Maar in hoeverre zien we de verschuiving naar meer verantwoordelijkheden voor burgers ook daadwerkelijk terug in wet- en regelgeving? Is er een verschil tussen beleidsretoriek en wat er daadwerkelijk verandert, bijvoorbeeld als het gaat om aansprakelijkheid? En kunnen we in Nederland wel beslissen over hoe we jeugdzorg en ggz vormgeven, of zijn we hierbij ook gebonden aan internationale mensenrechtenverdragen?

Zorg door netwerken van professionals en informele zorgverleners vraagt wat van organisaties. Datzelfde geldt voor samenwerking tussen professionals uit verschillende sectoren en voor samenwerking tussen het gemeentelijke en het nationale niveau. Hoe zorg je ervoor dat verschillende organisaties op de hoogte zijn van elkaars activiteiten en dat zij elkaar versterken in plaats van tegenwerken?

Niet alleen op organisatie- of teamniveau verandert er veel. Ook op het microniveau van professionals, cliënten, en hun omgeving kunnen beleidsveranderingen grote gevolgen hebben. Inzichten uit de sociaal-medische wetenschappen helpen bij het beantwoorden van vragen als: Wat betekent ‘eigen regie’ voor cliënten en hun naasten? Wat gebeurt er als die eigen regie conflicterend is met wat professionals onder goede zorg en ondersteuning verstaan? En wat vraagt dit van buurten?

In de internationale week zoeken we naar een antwoord op de vraag: in welk land kun je het beste kind zijn? We vergelijken beleid en wetgeving rondom jeugdzorg in verschillende landen. Tijdens deze week oefen je ook met het spreken en discussiëren in het Engels.

Ook ga je in dit blok (verder) met je academische vaardigheden. Hoe kun je kwalitatief onderzoek doen naar vraagstukken rondom beleid, wetgeving, organisaties, professionals en cliënten in het sociale domein? En hoe presenteer je je bevindingen op een manier die recht doet aan de complexiteit van de vraagstukken, maar ook begrijpelijk en bruikbaar is voor de praktijk? Je doet een groepsonderzoek in de praktijk.
Hieraan werk je tijdens dit gehele blok. Bekijk de pagina Persoonlijke en Professionele Ontwikkeling voor meer informatie.

column1: This course presents an overview of the key concepts in the social sciences that are essential to the academic study of communication and media. It will familiarize students with fundamental insights into the principles, perspectives, theories and concepts used in the field of social sciences, while applying a global perspective. The course highlights concepts such as society, culture, social change, social interaction, organizations, work and consumption, social stratification, power and social movements. Course activities include discussions of key issues and questions, assignments, and on- and offline assessments testing students' knowledge.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The nature, history and significance of the field of social science;
• The basic theories, principles and concepts used in the social sciences;
• The recent global and cultural 'turns' in social analysis.

column1: Students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Apply basic social scientific concepts and theories to different societal and cultural phenomena;
• Employ a global perspective when looking at social and cultural phenomena
• Formulate their own viewpoints and research questions, using relevant theoretical insights and concepts.

column1: The course focuses on the co-constitution of thinking and doing allowing students to learn how to orient themselves relationally. The emphasis is on a pedagogy of the senses, in which we approach experience as something that is produced, and therefore, can be designed. We thus explore architecture and philosophy as arts of creating concepts, perceptions and actions, leading to the eventual production of new modes of existence. The course is structured around key philosophical concepts such as: the Anthropocene, habit and habitat, place and space, virtuality, technicity,  individuation, information, generative and speculative design.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Upon completion of the three modules, the students will have:

o Acquired the academic skills for thinking, reading, presenting, and collaborating in an inclusive and transdisciplinary manner, in particular a sensibility for problems at the interface of architecture and philosophy;
o Acquired a conceptual toolbox for thinking in terms of relations and speculative-interactive design;

o Learned to apply contemporary ideas and debates in a dynamic urban setting in engaged, responsible, and non-reactive ways; Acquired or developed basic (technical) design skills while contributing to ecological literacy.

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Although academic knowledge and skills form the core of clinical graduate programs, an explicit focus on self-awareness and self-care as part of training is also critical. As Socrates already noted: “let him who would move the world, first move himself”. When health care professionals become more proficient in the exploration of their own inner worlds, and learn to attend to themselves in a kind and healing way, the greater their ability to help their clients.

Mindfulness can be described as the awareness that arises through intentionally attending in an open, caring, and discerning way. Research shows that the practice of mindfulness has positive effects on numerous mental and physical health outcomes within clinical and non-clinical populations. In the present elective course, we introduce mindfulness as a means of maintaining therapist health and well-being, as well as a systematic way of training key therapist skills (e.g., attention and presence, curiosity, kindness and compassion, emotion regulation), eventually manifesting in stronger therapeutic alliances and improved treatment outcomes.

We will start each week’s session with self-awareness training using formal and informal meditation and inquiry practices derived from the mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBCT) and mindfulness-based compassionate living (MBCL) programs. Then relevant scientific literature on concepts, working mechanisms, and neurobiological underpinnings is discussed. We will end each session with concrete exercises and group discussions that will help translate the learned skills to daily life and the clinical practice (including exercises derived from acceptance and commitment therapy; ACT). In between sessions you will practice at home by meditating, reading, keeping logs, conducting small behavioral experiments, and reflecting upon it all. The course is concluded with a final report in which you will critically reflect upon what you’ve learned in each of the sessions, whilst establishing explicit links to scientific research and possible clinical applications.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Upon successful completion of the sessions and assignments of this 5-week course on mindfulness, you will be able to:

column2: • Define mindfulness and describe the working mechanisms and effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions on various (health) outcomes in diverse populations, including helping professionals.
• Demonstrate attentional focus and shifting modes from thinking/conceptual to sensing/embodied, and from focused concentration to open monitoring.

• Develop the ability to come off autopilot in daily life situations, by tuning into the present moment, noticing inner processes (thoughts, emotions, physical sensations), and consciously choosing how to respond (i.e. develop a pause button).
• Process difficult emotions and uncomfortable feelings by holding them in awareness with an attitude of curiosity, self-kindness and self-acceptance.
• Demonstrate mindful listening skills; non-judgmentally attending to self and others with care and compassion.
• Apply self-care skills in stressful situations
• Demonstrate self-reflective skills; i.e., the ability to communicate about personal experiences.
• Apply all abovementioned core practices and skills within a professional context.

column1: Gezondheidszorg is een complex beleidsdomein waarin publieke, private en professionele belangen door elkaar lopen. Dit leidt soms tot lastige vraagstukken, zoals: Wat is de beste balans tussen individuele en collectieve verantwoordelijkheden, tussen collectieve en private financiering, tussen publieke en private uitvoering, tussen samenwerking en concurrentie, en tussen nationaal en gedecentraliseerd beleid? Het antwoord op deze vragen, zo zullen we zien, verschilt naar gelang de context en het gehanteerde perspectief. Zo kan het er anders uit zien voor de ziekenhuiszorg dan voor de jeugdzorg, en treden verschuivingen op in de tijd.

In dit vak krijgen studenten de kennis en vaardigheden aangereikt die nodig zijn om bovengenoemde vraagstukken te begrijpen en analyseren, en om mee te denken over de inrichting van het Nederlandse zorgstelsel. Dit vraagt om een multidisciplinaire aanpak met gedachtegoed vanuit de bestuurskundige, juridische en economische wetenschappen.

Tijdens interactieve colleges en werkgroepen worden studenten uitgedaagd om relevante concepten en theorieën toe te passen op concrete vraagstukken in verschillende domeinen van de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg zoals de curatieve zorg, langdurige zorg, jeugdzorg en maatschappelijke ondersteuning. Bijzondere aandacht gaat uit naar de rol van zorgverzekeringen en zorgverzekeraars in het Nederlandse zorgstelsel. Daarnaast besteden we aandacht aan de rol van de overheid en de rol van toezichthouders.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• kritisch reflecteren op verschillende instrumenten en thema’s rondom innovaties in de gezondheidszorg aan de hand van verschillende theoretische perspectieven
• analyseren welke instrumenten wanneer ingezet kunnen worden, en wat de mogelijke consequenties van deze keuzes zijn
• de gevolgen van theoretische keuzes voor praktisch handelen overzien
• de praktische implicaties van innovatieprocessen in de zorg beschrijven en beargumenteren

column1: In dit vak staan de specifieke methodologische eisen en problemen centraal die verbonden zijn aan kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden. Kwalitatief onderzoek verschilt op belangrijke punten van kwantitatief onderzoek. Er wordt met een ander type gegevens gewerkt; geen databestanden die met statistische methoden bewerkt kunnen worden, maar verzamelde documenten, interviews en observaties die met theoretische concepten worden geanalyseerd. Er worden specifieke eisen gesteld aan de validiteit en de betrouwbaarheid van onderzoeksresultaten. Studenten leren al doende wat kwalitatief onderzoek inhoudt.

Het vak is opgezet aan de hand van studieopdrachten die leiden tot het opstellen van een onderzoeksvoorstel voor een leeronderzoek dat in een onderzoeksgroepje (3 studenten) zal worden uitgevoerd. De studieopdrachten gaan over de belangrijke overwegingen die studenten moeten maken bij het opzetten van een kleinschalig, maar wetenschappelijk verantwoord onderzoeksproject. Studenten kunnen de studieopdrachten uit de werkgroep direct aan hun eigen onderzoeksverslag koppelen. De werkgroepdocenten begeleiden de onderzoeksgroepjes bij het schrijven van voorstel, het daadwerkelijk uitvoeren van kwalitatief onderzoek en het schrijven van het verslag dat gebaseerd is op het onderzoeksvoorstel en op een eerste analyse van de zelf verzamelde, getranscribeerde en gecodeerde data. Een individuele zelfreflectie van elke student is toegevoegd.

Er worden vier hoorcolleges gegeven over de algemene thema's in het vak. In de werkgroep wordt de opgegeven literatuur besproken en de opdracht gemaakt. Op basis van de werkgroepbijeenkomst kan de opdracht door de studenten zelf verder worden uitgewerkt in het onderzoeksvoorstel/verslag. Belangrijk is dat studenten de opgegeven literatuur lezen en de opdrachten voorbereiden. Het vak wordt afgesloten met een beoordeling van het verslag en de zelfreflectie.

<body>In het eerste jaar is geoefend met het analyseren van kwantitatieve (d.w.z. cijfermatige) data. Soms maken onderzoekers in onderzoeksprojecten echter geen gebruik van kwantitatieve data, maar van kwalitatieve data zoals interviewtranscripten, beleidsnota’s, neerslag van (video-)observaties, et cetera. In dit practicum leren studenten over de wijze waarop deze kwalitatieve (niet in cijfermatige grootheden uitgedrukte) data kan worden geanalyseerd, en wordt hierbij speciale aandacht gegeven aan het gebruik van ICT hulpmiddelen (Atlas.TI) hierbij.</body>

column1: Tijdens dit vak schrijven studenten een onderzoeksverslag in groepsverband. Meerdere groepjes werken binnen 1 thema en ieder groepje binnen een thema werkt een deelaspect uit tot een zelfstandig onderzoeksverslag. Het onderzoek is kwantitatief van aard. De begeleider voorziet de studenten van een dataset. Tijdens de bijeenkomsten en feedback momenten krijgt de student uitleg over het schrijven van een goede tekst en het rapporteren van onderzoeksresultaten. Ongeveer één keer per twee weken heeft de student op vooraf gestelde tijdstippen een feedback gesprek met de begeleider, 3 keer met alle groepjes binnen een thema en 3 keer per individueel groepje. Vaardigheden die nodig zijn voor het uitvoeren van data-analyses zijn voornamelijk afkomstig uit Inleiding M&T en Statistiek A en B en worden waar nodig aangevuld door de begeleider tijdens computerpractica waarbij gebruik wordt gemaakt van het softwareprogramma SPSS.

column1: This course constitutes an introduction to the field of labour economics with a focus on the influence of labour market institutions. Labour market institutions are quite diverse across countries. For example, in some countries there are strict rules concerning hiring and firing of workers, in other countries these rules are less strict. Some countries have relative low unemployment benefits, others have high; some countries put a lot of money in active labour market policy while other countries restrict themselves to passive labour market policy, i.e. providing benefits to unemployed workers. Not only the institutions are different between countries; there are also differences in labour market performance in terms of unemployment rates, participation rates, job creation et cetera. Now that borders between countries are vanishing due to globalization it is interesting to investigate the nature of the differences in labour market performance. The course presents an overview of labour market theories supported by practical examples and statistics illustrating differences in institutions between OECD countries.

• To learn about possible empirical approaches to analyse labour markets by studying examples.

column1: Course content and structure of the track
The LM Track comprises three thematic clusters and a final advisory assignment:

column2: • Cluster 1: Land rights and the rule of law (weeks 1, 2 and 3 of the track). Content coordinator: Ore Fika.
• Cluster 2: Land markets and finance (weeks 4 and 5 of the track). Content coordinator: Paul Rabé.
• Cluster 3: Land, water and natural resources (weeks 6 and 7 of the track). Content coordinator: Paul Rabé.
• Final advisory assignment: “Building Back Better” in a post-disaster context (weeks 8 and 9 of the track). Content coordinator: Paul Rabé.

column1: The final two weeks of the LM track comprises the examination period, which is devoted to the advisory assignment on “building back better” (BBB) in a post-disaster context. Students will have 1.5 weeks to work full-time on an advisory strategy, after which they will present their strategy to a real-life client during week 9 of the track and (if needed) revise their proposals following the professional presentation. The final (individual) paper, which is based on the participants’ BBB proposals, will be due immediately after the LM track.

column1: <body>At the end of the course participants should be able to:

column2: • Critically evaluate the dynamics, including relationships and conflicts, that exist in the governance of land, water and natural resources in connection to land rights, the rule of law, markets, finance, sustainability, and their impacts on urban and peri-urban areas, institutions and stakeholders.
• Propose fit-for-purpose/tailor-made land governance strategies and approaches to achieve inclusive, equitable and resilient urban and peri-urban areas.

<body>

column3: In deze cursus bestuderen we de mentale processen die betrokken zijn bij het gebruik van taal. Er zullen vier hoofdgebieden worden behandeld:

column4: <li>
<li>
<li>
<li>

column3: Vragen die hierbij aan de orde komen zijn onder andere: Hebben dieren taal? Welke delen van het menselijk brein zijn betrokken bij het gebruik van taal? Waarom is het voor volwassenen moeilijker een nieuwe taal te leren? Als we iets op een andere manier formuleren, leidt dit dan tot een nieuwe representatie? Hoe herkennen de hersenen geluidsgolven of krulletjes op papier als betekenisvolle woorden? Hoe leren mensen lezen? Hoe kiezen mensen de betekenis van dubbelzinnige woorden zoals ‘bank’? Hoe representeren mensen de betekenis van woorden en de relaties tussen woorden? Hoe kunnen mensen teksten begrijpen en onthouden? Hoe vertalen mensen gedachten in verbale uitingen? Op welke manier zijn taalproductie en taalbegrip verschillend? Hoe kunnen hersenbeschadigingen leiden tot taalstoornissen (afasie)? Op welke manieren kunnen wetenschappers deze vragen onderzoeken?</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Studenten krijgen in deze cursus kennis van en inzicht in de cognitief –en neuropsychologische aspecten van geschreven en gesproken taal. Veel aspecten van het gebruik van taal worden behandeld, en sommige onderwerpen zullen dieper worden bediscussieerd. Studenten zullen bekend raken met gangbare modellen van woordherkenning, taalbegrip, en taalproductie. Aan het eind van de cursus zullen de studenten inzicht hebben in de methoden die worden gebruikt door onderzoekers in dit veld.</body>

column1: <body>De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: From the mid-twentieth century onwards, most theorists agree, several social, technological, economic and institutional developments reconfigured western capitalist societies to the extent that we can speak of a shift from modernity to ‘late’ modernity. Large blue-collar industries got ‘out-sourced’ or ‘off-shored’, changing the economic basis of whole urban regions and the cultural geography of what came to be called the post-industrial city. Nation states, meanwhile, had to adapt to a new role in a globalizing economy, whilst partly delegating their sovereignty to supranational institutions. New communication technologies and consumer electronics altered the relation between space and time and the experience of the world. And the institutionalised drive towards neo-liberalisation redefined the relationship between citizens and nation states and markets, as well as inaugurated new regimes of capital accumulation and unprecedented levels of inequality. Despite all of these changes, the cognomen ‘late modernity’ indicates that these developments should not be conceived of as so many radical breaks with the processes that underpinned modernity, but rather as both a continuation and a transformation of these processes. As the course’s subtitle suggest, we will outline and analyse the shift from ‘classical modernity’ to ‘late modernity’ by focusing on the different, yet related processes of globalisation, neoliberalisation, and mediatisation.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course students are able to:

column2: • Describe and explain the process of globalization in terms of its technological conditions, political economy and media enterprises;
• Explain, and illustrate with examples, the ways in which the logic of networks affects the exclusion, inclusion and representation of social groups, social processes and/or events;
• Explain, and illustrate with examples, the ways in which the logic of mediatization affects the exclusion, inclusion and representation of social groups, social processes and/or events;
• Describe and explain the key features of communication power;
• Describe and explain the shift from Keynesian-Fordism to Flexible-Neoliberalism;
• Describe and explain the shift from disciplinary societies to control societies;
• Describe and explain the relation between globalization and global warming;
• Describe and explain the changed and changing nature of social movements since the worker movements of modernity.

column1: Law & Economics studies the economic effects of legal rules and legal institutions and their evolution over time. This course focuses on the most fundamental legal institution of our times: the business corporation, that is, a firm with “legal personality”. It unveils its origin, historical evolution and functions in a modern economy and explains the reach of an economic theory of legal entities.

This course brings the students to the cutting edge of research in Business Law & Economics. The course starts with an analysis of property rights and their importance for industrial organization and the theory of the firm. It then explores the economics of corporations, their essential differences with respect to unincorporated firms and the problem of dissolution through bankruptcy. The course focuses in particular on four features of the corporations, which have “proprietary rights” nature and are attached to the corporation’s qualification as a “legal entity”. Building on the economic theory of the firm, this course illustrates a theory of why some firms incorporate, what this means for property and contracts and for the market in general.
The course builds on very recent contributions in legal scholarship, finance and economics.

column1: <body>This course presents an economic theory of legal entities and unpacks the fundamental features of the corporation (a firm with legal entity status) examining their origins, evolution and functions in modern western economy. The most used and innovative theories are examined in detail and students will learn how to work with them. The material treated during the course is meant to give the students a perspective on current research trends and hot topics. This course is highly complementary to courses in corporate finance, contract theory, political economy and industrial organization.</body>

column1: Leiderschap is een groot thema in de literatuur. Veel onderzoekers hebben gekeken naar leiderschapsstijlen en strategieën. Ook de interactie met de werknemers die een leidinggevende aanstuurt, de zogenaamde volgens, is niet onderbelicht gebleven. Werkt elke strategie in dezelfde mate voor elke werknemer? Aangezien veel academisch geschoolden straks in een leidinggevende positie terecht komen, is het ook voor de praktijk zeer zinvol om hier bij stil te staan.

Een ander hoofdthema binnen dit blok is coaching. Als er één aandachtsgebied binnen het werkveld van de A&O psychologie enorm toegenomen is, is het coaching wel. Coaching vindt zijn oorsprong in de sportwereld en is overgewaaid naar het bedrijfsleven. Het beroep coach is niet beschermd, wat inhoudt dat iedereen zich coach mag noemen. Echter, de psychologische benadering van coaching komt voort uit psychologische theorieën en onderzoek. Belangrijke vragen zijn wat coaching precies inhoudt en hoe het kan bijdragen aan betere prestaties van werknemers. Is het coachen van een individuele werknemer zinvol, of worden er betere resultaten bereikt als er op teamniveau gecoacht wordt?
Verder worden studenten in dit blok uitgedaagd om kritisch te denken en om hun theoretische kennis toe te passen op situaties en casussen uit de praktijk.
Het blok is gestructureerd rond twee grote thema’s: leiderschap en coaching.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Dit blok is een verdieping binnen de arbeids- en organisatiepsychologie. Doel van dit blok is kennis te verwerven van psychologische theorieën over leiderschap en coaching. Daarnaast bestuderen we een aantal toepassingen van deze theorieën. De theorieën zijn veelal afkomstig uit de sociale en arbeid & organisatie psychologie en hebben directe relevantie voor veel processen in arbeidsorganisaties. Een van de hoofddoelen van dit blok is een brug slaan tussen de resultaten uit wetenschappelijk onderzoek en de dagelijkse A&O praktijk.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Leadership in today’s hyper-mediatized society is facing ever greater and dynamic challenges. In addition to mastering the traditional strategic areas of a business or organization, leaders of today and tomorrow also need to be excellent communicators in the face of their dramatically changing role, with implications for organization culture too.
Here are some of the big changes that are fundamentally reshaping all organizations.
1.  Technological changes creating deep and lasting disruptions everywhere, with impacts on businesses, society and all stakeholders.
2.  Regulatory zeal or other governmental influence is of increasing importance.
3.  Highly volatile and complex external context, where system thinking and understanding the ‘unthinkables’ will be required.
4.  Ever more scrutiny by NGOs and other stakeholders.
5.  At the same time, the trust is declining for all institutions: business, governments, NGOs and media.
6.  Media and social media drive ultra- transparency but also fake news!
7.  In this age of disruptions and fast moving changes, leadership communications require greater focus on resilience and changes in organization culture

This course will examine how leaders can turn risks into opportunity by strengthening their understanding of these issues, the role of stakeholder management and how they can deploy strategic communication embracing the new media to achieve this.</body>

column1: Students to acquire knowledge and understanding of:
•    Different academic perspectives on how multi-facetted societal and economic developments influence the demands of Leadership at micro and macro level.
•    Multi-dimensional thinking on new Leadership capabilities and the Communication imperative.
•    The new communication imperative for leadership, organisational culture and what this means in practice.
•    Analyze system thinking, the role of ‘unthinkables’ and how this affects leadership.
•    Understand different communications dimensions of today’s leadership capabilities.
•    Critically review the use of different Communications methods that can be deployed by Leadership and implications for organization culture.

column1: In modern organizations, employees are continuously expected to learn and improve themselves to cope with frequent changes. Leadership skill is one of the core aspects to develop for career advancement. The aim of this course is to establish a solid foundation of the key principles of leadership development based in the state of the science. The focus will be on both developing your own leadership potential and your ability to develop other’s leadership.

Together we will reflect on insights from leadership research, explore different approaches to leadership development such as 360-degree feedback, coaching, mentoring, and learning from experience. There will also be debates on “hot” topics in the field. For example, is adventure-based/outdoor training effective? Does mindfulness training help leadership development? Is online coaching going to work?

You are expected to actively participate during the lectures both in discussions and through in-class exercises. In addition to active in-class participation, you are expected to complete a number of assignments outside of the classroom, both individually and in small groups. There are also weekly short quizzes to consolidate and provide feedback to your learning.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to:
1.    Gain better insight into one's own leadership capacity and areas for personal growth and development through reflections;
2.    Develop critical thinking of research and practices in leadership development and training;
3.    Understand the systematic function and needs of training and development in organisations; and
4.    Evaluate and discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different leadership developmental and training initiatives.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The prominent leadership scholar James MacGregor Burns famously stated that leadership is one of the most observed but least understood phenomena on earth. The popularity of leadership can indeed hardly be overstated. For example, the term ‘leader’ results in almost one billion hits on Google and about 3 million on Google Scholar. Although leadership is a powerful term it is also often weakly conceptualised. In this course, we aim to move beyond this by discussing the notion of leadership in depth. We will study among other things the historical development of important leadership theories, discuss the differences and similarities of leadership in the public and private sector and show various methods to study leadership. When doing this, we will use insights from various disciplines, such as psychology, sociology, public administration, business administration. In this way, we increase our understanding of leadership so that students and professors can study it and practitioners can use these insights in their work.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • define the concept of leadership;
• understand and describe the various leadership approaches used in the last five decades;
• understand and describe the similarities and differences between leadership in the public and private domain;
• define and critically reflect on core leadership concepts (e.g. transformational leadership, transactional leadership, leader member exchange theory, attachment theory, and ethical leadership);
• describe and critically reflect on the relevance of emotions and power relations that make leadership possible and impossible in practice;
• describe and critically reflect on the reasons for change and change management;
• understand and describe what leaders can do to facilitate change;

column1: This course builds on the insights of the B1 course Organization and Management which has explained the essence of organizations, the relation between context and organization and the important role of management in shaping and guiding organizations. This course builds on this knowledge by discussing the role of leadership and Human Resource Management (HRM) within (international) organizations. This is based on the assumption that people (whether leaders or employees) are the most important resource of organizations.

More precisely, the course ‘Leadership and HRM in international organisations’ focuses on the role of leadership and HRM in today’s society and specifically in today’s volatile, uncertain, complex and ambiguous society. Throughout the course, we will elaborate on diverse HRM and leadership topics in international organizations and what the impact of context and societal transformations are on the way organizations are organized in terms of leadership and HRM. We address issues such as ‘What is HRM?’, ‘What is strategic HRM?’, ‘What is sustainable HRM?’, ‘Which HR practices can we distinguish and, how are those affected by international challenges?´, ´What is the role of (public) leadership for international organisations?´, ‘What is the meaning of work and, what do future-proof workplaces look like?’

Throughout the tutorials and the different assignments therein students will apply the concepts and theories presented and will be challenged to evaluate the role of leadership and HRM in a specific international organization. In addition, there are assignments in which students reflect on diverse leadership and HRM topics via practical cases, scientific journal papers, and own research based on a website scraping method.

• Explain what the role is of leadership and HRM given international challenges

column1: Leadership is a key factor in innovation. At the same time, the innovation context places unique demands on leadership. For example, different phases of the innovation process and different innovation types require specific leadership styles and behaviors. Moreover, leadership for innovation can be based on different paths: providing an own inspiring vision and getting employees to follow it or fostering employee creativity and innovation. In addition, innovation leaders are often empowered by the creativity of the crowd and need to orchestrate diverse ideas and viewpoints, in multidisciplinary teams. The demands on innovation leaders are further shaped by the unprecedented rate of technological and social change on a global level. To successfully lead for innovation, future leaders have to navigate the intricacies of the leadership-innovation relationship, while building on a strong understanding of how leadership mechanisms operate.

This hands-on course will equip you with the necessary knowledge and skills to become a successful innovation leader and coach. The course includes both the central scientific theory and evidence on leadership/coaching and innovation, as well as real-life cases and guest lectures. The course learnings will be delivered in an interactive way that includes a combination of case discussion and more experiential learning. You will be able to take note of relevant theories and understand how these may work in practice, through exercises and role-plays. Moreover, the course will include multiple sessions of coaching training. The objective of these sessions is to equip you with the necessary skills to coach and manage multidisciplinary project teams. After the weekly lectures/coaching training in Block 3, you will be able to apply your new coaching skills in Blocks 4 and 5, by coaching multidisciplinary teams of Bachelor students (BSc BA/IBA and BSc Applied Physics) who follow the course Technology Management. By taking part in this unique opportunity, you will be able to practice leading teams for innovation in a safe learning environment.

column1: Upon completion of the course you should be able to …

• Utilize coaching techniques and skills to inspire and motivate others to innovate.
• Coach interdisciplinary teams to successfully complete (technological) innovation projects.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98917,2021,Leading People, Teams, and Organisations for Excellence",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. IJ Hoever', 'dr. L van Bunderen, PhD']",,"Inhoud

<body>Organisations are complex social entities which are only successful if the people within them thrive and perform to their full potential. Leaders and managers play a critical role in helping individuals to reach this potential, to successfully collaborate to achieve a common purpose, and to leverage and respect the skills, insights, and experiences of a diverse range of employees. Fulfilling this role requires knowledge about how to shape behaviour and promote performance in organisations and practical skills to implement them. Through this course, we will therefore explore the core question of how to encourage people to thrive and deliver excellence for organisations from three different angles. These angles are captured in three themes:

column2: • Building successful teams: In the first theme, we focus on how individuals can productively collaborate in teams, which are a key building block of modern workplaces. Successful teams are critical for business success, but how can we help teams to function at their best?

• Leading others: In the second theme, we focus on how leaders can motivate, direct, and influence the behaviour of their followers. Leaders play a key role in helping employees realize their potential. At the same time leaders can be the source of demotivation and conflict. An understanding of how leadership can help people thrive and where it can go wrong is essential for effective organisational functioning.

• Managing diversity in the workplace: The third theme puts the management of diverse workforces centre stage to explore how we can build organisations in which a variety of employees thrive and perform. Managing today’s increasingly diverse workforce presents organisations with a challenge that is both complex and potentially rewarding. This theme discusses key theories of diversity and offers insights into best practices in diversity management in order to help you realize the benefits and avoid the pitfalls of diversity.

column1: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

The central purpose of this course is to give students insights into critical questions regarding teamwork, leadership, and diversity management within organisations. Specifically, the course covers three broad learning goals (listed below). Each of these learning goals covers the three content areas of the course: building successful teams, leading others, and managing diversity.

column2: • Knowledge acquisition & comprehension: After following this course, students should be able to understand and explain the major theories about, and factors that contribute to effective team dynamics, leadership, and diversity management.

• Practical application & problem solving: After following this course, students should be able to use the aforementioned theories and research findings to critically analyse and solve practical problems concerning team dynamics, leadership, and diversity management. This involves the ability to:
<ul style=""list-style-type:circle"">

column3: • Select and find relevant theories and research findings for a given problem or challenge.
• Use these theories and research findings to understand the causes and contingencies of the problem or challenge.
• Develop recommendations and solutions based on the theory and the particular circumstances of the challenge or problem.

column2: • Self-insight & self-development: After following this course, students should be able to identify the strengths and weaknesses in their own functioning as team members and leaders in settings characterised by various levels of diversity. This involves the ability to:
<ul style=""list-style-type:circle"">

column3: • Reflect on one’s own behaviours, biases, and functioning.
• Develop concrete plans of how to further improve.
• Put these plans into action and reflect upon their success.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99538,2021,Learning analytics & the design of online learning,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. BB de Koning', 'dr. HK Tabbers']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: One fascinating aspect of online learning environments is that learners will leave digital traces of their behavior. On the individual level this raises ethical questions about privacy, and it requires rules and regulations to provide learners with control over which information will and will not be shared. On the group level however, anonymized trace data provide a rich source of information for all stakeholders involved in organizing, designing, and providing online education or training.

In this practical you will get hands-on experience in this field of ‘learner analytics’: the use of digital trace data for analyzing learners’ online behavior. We will especially focus on the role of learning analytics for evaluating and optimizing the design of a specific online learning environment. You will be provided with actual trace data from an existing learning environment, and you will not only be analyzing these data, but also you will also have to come up with a redesign plan based on this analysis.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Being able to analyze learner analytics data with the purpose of testing hypotheses on (un)intended learner behavior.
• Being Being able to translate these findings into a plan for redesign of the learning environment.

column1: In this minor, you will work as consultants to (Rotterdam and surrounding area based) social entrepreneurs and non-profit organizations. This course is intended to strengthen the skills and specific knowledge of students and provides a very practical experience. Instead of working with fictitious cases, you will be working with real, existing organizations. This will allow you to apply the knowledge that you have gained thus far to a real-life situation. In addition, the work you will be doing is intended to benefit both your client organization and the larger community. Interesting cases are pre-selected by the instructors, but we are open for any suggestions from students.

column2: • become familiar with important issues and theories involving consultancy, social entrepreneurship, and the non-profit sector;
• develop skills in the application of theoretical concepts to real-life situations;
• gain experience with actual issues that arise in the course of a consultancy project;
• be guided through: your first meeting with the client, how to write a consultancy contract and report, the actual process of consultancy, and how to present your recommendations to your client;
• gain experience in finding, evaluating and applying relevant literature to the specific situation of a client organization;
• develop and strengthen your creativity, teamwork, project, communication, research, writing, intervision, and presentation skills.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98936,2021,Learning from big data,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Gabel', 'prof.dr. G Liberali']",,"Inhoud

Every day, millions of consumers voice their opinions in product-review websites, blogs, and chat rooms. They spontaneously produce massive amounts of user-generated content (UGC), most of which is textual and freely available for analysis. At the same time, online and offline retailers collect rich data sets that contain valuable information about the purchases of individual customers. In this era of big data, the availability of new, larger, and more diversified data sets creates exciting opportunities for marketing researchers and practitioners.

However, the characteristics of big data (volume, velocity, variety) also pose challenges for modelers. With so much data available, it can be hard to determine what information is correct or how to separate signal from noise. For example, how can you extract information about market structure and consumer preferences from purchase data? To make this even more difficult, UGC data are often unstructured and textual. Do you know how to analyze UGC data? And how do you go from insights to marketing decisions?

All that is needed to address these challenges is the right set of tools and the training that helps you to use the tools correctly. This course first teaches how to formalize marketing problems as statistical models. It then shows how to solve marketing problems by complementing classical econometric techniques with modern machine learning (ML) methods. You will find tools and conceptual frameworks needed to identify and exploit the opportunities that big data sources create.

The course has three modules, each containing lectures and hands-on activities. In the first module (“Mine your Own Business in Blogs, Reviews and Tweets”), we will work with various types of UGC, with a strong emphasis on textual data. We will discuss and use tools to help you automate the detection of both content and sentiment from texts produced by consumers. The second module (“Purchase Prediction with Boosted Trees”) focuses on the application of supervised ML methods to predictive and prescriptive marketing problems. The module also introduces important theoretical and practical principles for designing and implementing ML pipelines. In the third module (“Neural Networks–From Market Structure Analysis to Prescriptive Marketing”), we will use representation learning and deep learning techniques to model market structures in retailing applications and leverage insights for prescriptive marketing applications. There is one major “module assignment” to be handed in at the end of each module. In the assignments you will apply the methods, templates, and scripts seen during the lectures.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

This course will push you to develop new analytical skills and to be creative when devising solutions and interpreting your results to understand the consumer behavior that generated the data you are analyzing. In addition, you will not only apply existing modeling libraries but also implement models and algorithms (almost) from scratch. After completing this course, you will be able to judge how modern machine learning methods (ML) complement (or even replace) traditional statistical methods for data analysis and decision-making. The course is designed to prepare you for solving real-world marketing problems using modern quantitative methods and is a good preparation for a ML/data science job in marketing or a PhD in quantitative marketing.
The learning objectives of this course are to:

column2: <li>
Obtain insights on consumer preferences and behavior from user-generated data.
<li>
Understand the potential of user-generated content (UGC) to listen to the voice-of-the-consumer, expressed in unstructured data such as texts in blogs and product reviews.
<li>
Formalize marketing decisions as supervised or unsupervised machine learning problems.
<li>
Analyze real-world loyalty card data to solve prescriptive marketing problems.
<li>
Learn the necessary tools to efficiently implement machine learning models and pipelines.
<li>
Learn how to work in groups on ML and data science projects.

column1: This course will provide students of the Master in the Governance of Migration and Diversity with an introduction into the legal dimension of migration and diversity governance. This includes global migration law (including the Global Compact on Migration) as well as a specific focus on EU migration and asylum law (including Free Movement, Schengen, Dublin and Return policies). Furthermore, the course devotes attention to diversity law, in particular in the area of human rights and minority protection. At the end of the course students will have knowledge of the most important legal principles and structures and understand the relevance of these for the governance of migration and diversity. Furthermore, students will be challenged to analyse concrete governance dilemmas by considering their legal dimension.

column2: • Introduction: a legal perspective on the governance of migration and diversity
• Human rights and minority protection
• Global migration law
• Basics of European migration and asylum law
• EU Free Movement of Persons
• Schengen, Dublin and the Refugee crisis
• Return and return cooperation
• Written exam (60%).
• Essay in which students apply legal principles/structures to a concrete governance dilemma (40%).
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Study objectives. After this course, students will be able to

column2: • Identify the most important legal principles and structures in global and European migration law
• Identify the most important legal principles and structures in human rights law and minorities protection
• Understand the relevance and implications of these legal principles and structures for the governance of migration
• Apply legal principles and structures to concrete governance dilemmas.

column1: <body>Legal psychology aims to apply scientific psychological knowledge to the legal arena, particularly to criminal procedure. Hence, legal psychologists seek to study the behaviour of police, districts attorney, defence lawyer, judge, and jury. These parties may also ask legal psychologists explicitly for assistance. By and large, legal psychologists study the evidence used in court. In this course, various pieces of evidence, such as, witness statements including identifications, and suspect statements will be reviewed.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The main goal of this course is to offer an introduction of legal psychology to the student. The following topics will be introduced during this course: Witness testimony, suspect testimony, lie detection. Besides these specific topics, it is important to gain insight in legal psychology as a discipline, and to appreciate the position of the psychologist in the criminal procedure.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Legal psychology is a new and upcoming field where science and the profession of psychology    is applied to questions and issues relating to law and the legal system. As a legal psychologist, you will be called upon to answer a broad range of difficult questions, such as, but not limited to:

column2: • Is there a relationship between the mental disorder of a suspect and their behavior during the crime?
• How big is the risk that someone will re-offend in the future?
• How valid is the suspects confession?

column1: You will provide the judge with advice in criminal proceedings so the group of patients you'll work with will be diverse and demanding. They may have severe antisocial behavior and/or co- morbid mental disorders (such as schizophrenia combined with substance abuse disorders).

You will also need knowledge in the field of material law and legal procedures to be effective as an expert witness in court, for example being able to evaluate certain pieces of evidence. This means that you will need a very particular skillset.

This course will provide a small taste to the vast and wide world of legal psychology ranging from reliability of witness statements, the validity of confession evidence, interrogation techniques and avoiding professional biases. This is just the tip of the iceberg!

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>During this course, the following topics will be dealt covered:

column2: • Cognitive bias in legal decision making.
• How to prevent bias with a Bayesian approach to evidence.
• Identification evidence.
• Confession evidence.
• Lie detection.

column1: The aims of the course are to give students knowledge regarding core questions of contemporary legal theory and to help them develop their own critical perspective on the enterprise of law.

The students are required to study central articles by contemporary legal theorists and examine their arguments together (i); students are required to prepare assignments on set topics (ii); the exam will test students’ knowledge by setting problems, related to the literature, that allow students to show their argumentative skill as well (iii).

column1: The aim of the Life Support course is to give you a basic training in acute medicine and to experience ‘real’ working situations with help of some specially trained actors. The emphasis of the course is on the quick recognition of acute situations, clear communication, and adequate handling. We talk about how situations differ between inside and outside of the hospital, and between first-aid and professional medical care personnel.

During the course, the term ‘victim’ is frequently used. This term indicates a person who has an acute, (non-)life threatening disorder in her/his physical or mental health.  And who, in her/his own opinion or that of others, needs help. The common theme throughout the course is the ABCDE approach. This protocol is used internationally for the structured assessment and care of an acutely ill or wounded patient. In this course, the basic principles of this protocol will be taught. You will also learn e.g. how to assess the safety of a situation, call for help and perform CPR with or without the help an automated external defibrillator (AED).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Following this programme, the student is able to:

column2: • Assess the vital functions according to the ABCDE protocol and provide adequate treatment to disorders of the vital functions;
• Carry out adequate resuscitation according to NRR guidelines when faced with circulatory arrest;
• Provide adequate First Aid to accident victims (including treatment of wounds and bites; bandaging; removing splinters).

column1: This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Hermeneutics understands man as a self-interpreting animal, constructing itself through interpretation of its relation to the other and to historically produced culture. In this course, we will look at recent developments in culture that affect such interpretive self-understanding, and conversely at ways in which contemporary man produces this culture – as man and culture are mutually constitutive phenomena.
This course has two dimensions, which will interactively be presented in alternating weeks.

The first dimension deals with a variety of very recent developments in media, culture and science, such as digitalization, interculturalization and naturalization. The omnipresent informatization challenges hermeneutics to rethink the nature of human interpretation in the age of digital culture. Connecting to the work of Benjamin, Heidegger, and Simondon we will discuss the impact of hypermedia and game culture on writing and reading in the humanities? Secondly, global interculturalization challenges hermeneutics to reflect on the possibility and limits of intercultural understanding and interpretation. Starting from the work of Gadamer and Derrida, the focus will be on the question whether we can understand cultures in which we do not participate or only do so superficially. Thirdly, hermeneutics is challenged by the naturalization brought forth by disciplines like genetics and neurosciences and the accompanying converging technologies. Hermeneutics should not only analyze the impact of the ‘colonization’ of the humanities by the natural sciences in disciplines like evolutionary and  neuropsychological aesthetics, but also study the interpretative metaphors in these disciplines (e.g. ‘reading and writing genetic code’) and – following the work of Plessner, Thompson and Barbieri, - develop bio-hermeneutical, neuro-phenomenological and bio-semiotic complements to these disciplines.

The second dimension provides an analysis from a social and political perspective and discusses the power relations in society that affect, or interferes with, each of the aforementioned developments. This results in three challenges that form a counterpoint to those in the first half of the course. We discuss the phenomenon of mediatization, especially as analyzed by Benjamin in his Artwork essay; the role of the public sphere in relation to power, resistance, communication, and technology; the relation between technology, politics, and the phenomenon of outsourcing, or ‘interpassivity’; and the current issues around algorithms and their influence on politics and biopower.</body>

2) grasping hermeneutically and critically  the transformation of human life through power and global technologies

3) understanding the historical and cultural importance of hermeneutics for philosophy, and the challenges posed to it by the processes of interculturalization, informatization, and naturalization.</body>

column1: Literary movements and - styles do not emerge in a vacuum but are closely related to their proponent’s relation to the literary tradition, their reaction to their social context and their attitudes towards the future. There is, in other words, a politics of literature as much as a literature of politics. From the Romantic poet Percy Bysshe Shelly to contemporary hip-hop icon Kendrick Lamar, literary artists have been unambiguously preoccupied with questions of power, resistance and agency. Taking the emergence of ‘modern’ literature around 1800 as a starting point, this course will trace some of the relations between literature and politics up until the present. Rather than privileging one type of politics of literature over the other, students will engage with multifarious constellations of literature and politics through different theoretical orientations, historical contexts and literary genres. Each week will be centred around a particular theme (e.g. Literary Autonomy, The Politics of Literary Form, Literature and Community). We will read theoretical texts in conjunction with literary texts, from graphic novels to radical poetry and from feminist auto-fiction to utopian afrosci-fi. Ultimately, this course aims to provide students with the conceptual and analytical tools to reflect on and reimagine the possible relations between literature and politics.

<body>Tijdens dit blok ga je aan de slag met het schrijven van een wetenschappelijk literatuuronderzoek. Het leren schrijven van een literatuuronderzoek is zeer nuttig, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van leeronderzoeken en scripties, daar het vertrekpunt van al het sociologische onderzoek gevormd wordt door de grondige bestudering van eerder onderzoek. Tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst wordt uitgelegd waar een goed geschreven literatuuronderzoek aan moet voldoen. De daarop volgende bijeenkomsten staan in het teken van het opzetten, schrijven en verbeteren van het literatuuronderzoek; te beginnen met het opstellen van een goede probleemstelling en eindigend met het doen van aanbevelingen voor vervolgonderzoek.</body>

column1: Throughout the first week, the course will cover the main concepts that underpin successful local government finance structures in the sense of intergovernmental fiscal relations and fiscal decentralization. It will look at the most common revenue sources (including taxes, usage fees, and intergovernmental payments investment profits, land sales, and licenses and permits and external funding) available to local governments, as well as the problems that come with them and the key challenges that come with revenue management.

During this week, the course will also look at the problems that come with developing capital investment strategies and the funding sources that go with them. It will include both traditional and novel instruments and processes that municipalities use to access additional funding for capital investment financing by borrowing and capital markets. Debt management, creditworthiness, intergenerational equity, and the effects of development partner financing will all be examined closely. The use of analytical tools to evaluate the financial condition of a local government will conclude the first week.

The selection and prioritization of infrastructure project proposals is an important and challenging decision-making problem faced by decision makers, particularly in local governments. During the second week, the course will review some of the key decision analysis theories and approaches related to investment projects, with a focus on economic and financial analysis. The conceptual foundations of economic and financial Cost Benefit Analysis will be addressed by reviewing the key microeconomic concepts that can be applied to the measurement of costs and benefits. The discounted cash flow analysis principle will be applied to concrete examples of investment projects. Among others cash flow modelling, project lifetime period, net present value, discount rate, and risk will be reviewed. Excel spreadsheets will be used to build an investment decision-making framework related to a hypothetical toll road project and risk and sensitivity analysis will be carried out to incorporate uncertainty and probability in decision analysis.

The main underlying question for this course is: How will our local governments (cities) pay for the cities that are needed in this era of rapid urbanization and increasingly complex responsibilities, including uncertainties, pandemics included? This course focuses on local governments' ability to prepare, administer, and budget for essential public services and investments (local governments' fiscal health).

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Considering this, the course introduces and addresses the core concepts underlying successful local government finance focused on the fiscal health of cities, as well as a variety of analytical approaches for the economic and financial analysis of investment projects implemented by local governments under conditions of uncertainty.
At the end of the course the participant should be able to:

column2: • Understand, explain, and discuss the key principles and elements of local government finance including fiscal decentralisation, revenue management, and capital investment planning.
• Understand, explain, and apply analytical tools to evaluate the financial condition of a local government.
• Understand, explain, and discuss the key principles and elements in the selection and prioritization process of infrastructure project proposals in local governments.
• Understand and apply economic and financial analysis to investment projects relevant to local governments and incorporate uncertainty and probability in decision analysis.

column1: Whilst the 21st century has advanced our capabilities in many ways, that too brings with it many societal concerns, such as the poverty, diversity, immigration, global warming, media usage and well-being, to name a few. During this elective, students will explore societal issues of the 21st century and more importantly, in groups of five, collaborate with the goal of creating realistic and feasible solutions to prevent/alleviate these issues. Each group of students will be paired up with an academic supervisor to guide them along the way of contacting external stakeholders, measuring the effects of their proposed solution, presenting their findings and ‘giving back’ to the community in a way they see fit, based on the content of their project.

column2: • Given that you will be working with external stakeholders within the Rotterdam area, this elective is only for students who will be in the NL during the first semester.

• The groups will be designed in a way where we can best suit your area of interest. Once the elective registration deadline has passed, the coordinator will send you a survey to investigate what societal issues you are keen on focusing on. Groups will be formed based on the findings of the survey. It cannot be guaranteed that you will work on your desired project. But we will try our best.
• The goal is to have Dutch and International students working together on a project. Therefore, it is not possible you choose who you will be working with throughout the elective.

column1: Varies per group. Dependent on the content of the project at hand.

Once weekly study skills sessions: You will cover various themes with the goal of developing your soft skills (e.g. time management, the writing process, group collaboration skills etc.). This session will be guided by the course coordinator.
Once weekly group work sessions: You will meet with your peers within your own team to discuss your POA, work on your proposal, end products and the process as a whole.
Once weekly check-ins with your academic supervisor (via online/in person – dependent on what you agree with him/her).

This elective deviates from the norm in that it starts during week 2 of block 2 (minor/exchange period) until the end of block 3. What is good to note is that it will require the same amount of hours as all other electives. The bulk of your work is expected during the elective period when you will carry out your project. However some prep work is involved before you begin (circa 12 hours throughout block 2 – brainstorming & writing your proposal).

NB: We will start with a brainstorm session, to be held on Tuesday October 19th  (9:00 – 11:45). During this session, groups will be formed and you will collaborate and decide on your proposed solution. This session is mandatory so it is important you ensure you are free at this time (i.e. it does not clash with your minor timetable).

column1: In het zeventiende-eeuwse Engeland vinden grote natuurwetenschappelijke en filosofische veranderingen plaats die zich institutioneel kristalliseren rondom de Royal Society, waarvan eminente wetenschappers als Robert Boyle and Isaac Newton lid waren. Het empirisme van John Locke dient in deze context begrepen te worden. De latere zeventiende eeuw ziet ook een nieuwe generatie van rationalisten als Leibniz en Nicolas Malebranche, die voortgaan met de verdieping van begrippen als 'substantie' en 'causaliteit'. Voorts worden, opnieuw in Engeland, belangrijke bijdragen geleverd aan de politieke filosofie en ethiek door onder anderen Locke, diens leerling de derde graaf van Shaftesbury, en Herman Mandeville.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Op het eind van de cursus hebben de studenten kennis en begrip van de twee belangrijkste kentheoretische stromingen van de zeventiende eeuw en kunnen zij deze plaatsen binnen de contekst van de stormachtige veranderingen op het gebied van de natuurwetenschappen.</body>
