</style>

column1: What is information? Is all information truthful, meaningful, and descriptive of some state of affairs? What does it mean to be or to become informed about a certain state of affairs? When is information genuinely new or plainly redundant, and when are certain pieces of information (in)compatible? If I have information about your information, then what can I infer from it – what is the logic of such higher-order information? And what do each of us individually have to know, for us as a group to know something? What are the effects of communication on the information states of those individuals and groups who are involved in such communication? When is communication (through language or otherwise) succesful?

These questions involve numerous theoretical concepts and distinctions, but are also of great importance for how we study communication, information, and cognition in practice. The  primary aim of this course is to familiarize the students with standard theoretical perspectives on information, with some elementary models from philosophical logic that help to make them precise, and with important philosophical criticisms and shortcomings of the standard perspectives.

The course consists of a traditional, lecture-based part (70%) that introduces the above-mentioned topics and concepts, and a second part (30%) in which the students get to do some research on those topics themselves, focusing on a limited number of journal articles and book chapters, and with the primary aim of understanding the relation between such specific work and the overall themes of the course.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: 1. Explain and illustrate key distinctions and notions in the philosophy of information: quantitative vs. qualitative measures of information, syntactic versus semantic theories of information, factivity, entropy, redundancy.

2. Use tools and notions from propositional logic to explain in what sense information is “new” compared to a given body of information or when two pieces of information are “compatible”, and to model simple informational updates in terms of truth tables.
3. Explain and apply the basic methodology and insights from the theory of belief revision.
4. Use tools and notions from modal logic to reason about higher-order and group information.

5. Create and solve knight-knave riddles and explain how doing so relates to the mathematical theory of communication, in particular to query problems and strategies, expected query length, Huffman coding, and data compression.

6. Explain how self-referential questions can be invoked to solve knight-knave riddles and query problems more efficiently and relate such questions to the Liar paradox, which shows that our firmest intutions concerning truth are inreconcilable with classical logic.

7. Explain and apply the framework of assertoric semantics and its rules and norms for assertion and denial; use the framework to analyse the Liar paradox and show how the framework gives rise to non-classical logic.
8. Explain and criticize some received philosophical views on truth, in paricular deflationinsm, according to which our truth predicate soleley fulfills an expressive, communicative role.

9. Explain and criticize some received philosophical views on assertion, in particular on those theories according to which assertion is characterized by a constitutive norm such as truth, knowledge or justified belief.
10. Read and critically appraise original work in the philosophy of information, philosophy of language, and/or philosophical logic, and present it to peers and lecturers
11. Use original work in the philosophy of information, philosophy of language, and/or philosophical logic to develop an original opinion on a specific issue relevant for the course.</body>

column1: Students that would like to gain some practical experience during the Master program, can do so by means of an internship. Students can use one of the elective blocks to do a full time internship.

Instead of an elective a so-called business project can be carried out. This business project will be shorter than a regular internship. The advantage is that such a project can be carried out during one of the three elective blocks. A student can come up with a business project at a company of his or her choice. At the end of the internship the student will hand in a report.

The business project can be related to the thesis. However, this is not a requirement. Please not that even the two are linked, the business project will be assessed separately from the thesis itself and should contain another focus than the thesis. Please consult your thesis coach in case you want to combine your internship with you thesis.
<u>THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR MI STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS</u>: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two MI programme electives!</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In het vak maatschappelijke problemen en bestuurlijke oplossingen maken de studenten kennis met de wereld van de maatschappelijke problemen, het openbaar bestuur en de bestuurskunde. Ze leren in essentie wat het openbaar bestuur is, op welke wijze het openbaar bestuur tracht maatschappelijke problemen op te lossen en wat de rol van het vakgebied van de bestuurskunde hierbij is. Daarbij wordt specifiek ingegaan op de organisatie van het openbaar bestuur en de processen die daarin een rol spelen. De centrale vraag daarbij is welke principes van bestuurlijke vormgeving ten grondslag liggen aan de organisatie van het openbaar bestuur en welke spanningen daarbij kunnen optreden. Deze kennis vormt het basale vertrekpunt voor de verdere opleiding.</body>

column1: Machine learning is a key driver of the success of data-driven decision-making in business. It enables practitioners to learn from experience, as encoded in data, to understand business-relevant processes or to predict the future. It is an essential tool in the modern data scientist's toolbox.

This course provides a hands-on introduction to the concepts, principles and key algorithms for supervised and unsupervised machine learning. You will learn how these algorithms work and practice applying them to solve business problems. Attention will also be paid to principles, concepts and best practices which are required to apply these methods judiciously in practice, such as generalization, overfitting, resampling methods and evaluation metrics. The supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms covered will include decision trees, random forests, neural networks, cluster analysis and gradient boosting machines.

Machine Learning & Learning Algorithms is a core course in the MScBA Business Analytics & Management programme. It builds on knowledge obtained in the pre-modules and other core courses, with specific emphasis on statistics and programming. It provides knowledge and skills which will be leveraged to varying degrees by the elective courses.

column1: After taking this course, students will be able to:

• Understand and compare several fundamental supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms
• Apply these machine learning algorithms to business problems and their accompanying data sets in a principled way using R
• Communicate the results of such applications in various formats
• Demonstrate critical thinking when assessing the merits of machine learning projects

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98953,2021,Macroeconomics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['AG Andrei, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course aims to broaden students’ perspectives and knowledge about Macroeconomics. The course content extends beyond a classical Economics/Macroeconomics course focused on key economic indicators (e.g., GDP, inflation, unemployment, aggregate demand, aggregate supply, etc.). This elective incorporates theory, practical implications, and economic puzzles, all relevant to a dynamic and constantly evolving world.

We start by identifying the primary schools of thought in Macroeconomics and discussing to what extent these schools are in agreement and the likely consequences of any disagreements. We then continue with an applied perspective on the classical key Macroeconomic indicators. The idea is to understand these indicators in practice rather than only theoretically. For this reason, we will first cover theoretical concepts and then play online simulations to see their impact in practice. The third component/module of the course addresses shocks to economies. The shocks will naturally refer to economic crises, but the discussion will also address the impact of phenomena such as crypto-currencies and political instabilities in critical world regions. The fourth, and last module, brings attention to the existence of unsolved Macroeconomic puzzles. These puzzles refer to situations where the implication of the theory is inconsistent with observed economic data. For example, we will explore puzzles such as those from Behavioral economics (e.g., revealed preference puzzle), Financial economics (e.g., dividend puzzle), or Capital theory (e.g., Cambridge capital controversy). While we will not be able to nor aim to dive into detail in such unsolved puzzles in Macroeconomics, the course aims to contribute to a comprehensive perspective of Macroeconomics by raising awareness of these continuing debates’ existence.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Describe and compare the different schools of thought in Macroeconomics.
• Understand the dynamics of an economy, more specifically concepts of monetary and fiscal policy, aggregate demand and aggregate supply.
• Define and explain macroeconomic concepts and their dynamic interaction under “normal” and crises conditions.
• Evaluate an economy’s state and recognize the potential for improving the country’s economic health.
• Assess the impact/potential impact of macroeconomic factors/conditions/decisions on population approval ratings and implications for businesses
• Critically assess the potential impact of unpredicted events (see covid-19) on economies’ health.
• Develop an appreciation of the multidimensionality of Macroeconomics.
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Macroeconomics is the study of the structure and working of an economy as a whole, rather than of individual markets. It defines the main variables in the aggregate economy (GDP, inflation, unemployment), and studies how they behave, in particular how they react to economic shocks and policy decisions, over different time horizons. Two important subjects of macroeconomics can be identified: the study of the causes and consequences of short-run fluctuations in national income (the business cycle), and that of the determinants of long-run economic growth (increases in national income). We will see how macroeconomic models and their predictions are used by governments to assist in the development and evaluation of economic policy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will develop a simple macroeconomic model that allows us to analyse the evolution of the main macroeconomic aggregates in the short, medium and long run. We will also critically discuss policy debates, so that we directly observe how economic theory can be used to understand the real world.

The course builds on Macroeconomics I and applies dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models to the analysis of monetary and fiscal policy. It consists of four main parts. In the first part, we compare the inequality implications of a complete markets and a standard incomplete markets model when households face idiosyncratic income risk. Afterwards, we develop a basic competitive equilibrium framework which serves as the main building block for the course. The second part focuses on the role of fiscal policy. Here, effects of government spending, the role of public debt, and optimal taxation under commitment will be discussed. The third part introduces money into the framework and derives principles for optimal monetary policy under perfectly flexible prices. Further, the issues of monetary policy implementation and the determination of the price level will be addressed. The last part extends monetary policy analysis to the case where prices are imperfectly flexible. Within this framework optimal monetary policy under commitment and discretion will be examined.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
Learning goals for this course: students should have learned to
1. understand the link between insurance and individual consumption
2. solve dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models
3. show whether a long-run equilibrium exists and is unique, and derive conditions for a unique and stable set of policy functions
4. formally compute optimal tax and monetary policies in general equilibrium models
5. understand the economic mechanism why a certain policy is optimal</body>

column1: Instructors: Prof. E.J. Bartelsman (VU) and Prof. P. Gautier (VU)

Key macro indicators— unemployment, GDP, and productivity growth— may not follow the optimal paths determined in a frictionless economy. Recent models are much more careful in dealing with frictions agents face in reality, such as entry and exit fees, delays in finding transaction partners, information asymmetries, and limited contract enforcement. In this course, we explore the implications of heterogeneous agents facing various frictions that frustrate the allocation of resources in labor, capital and product markets.

By studying these models, students not only learn key aspects of three important topics in macroeconomics, namely labor market developments, business cycle analysis, and long-run growth, but also key building blocks that are useful by themselves.

We briefly discuss empirical regularities observed in the data regarding labor markets, firm demographics and productivity growth. After highlighting the difficulties of standard models to explain these regularities, we explore recent modifications. We start the labor market and discuss different ways to model how agents search, match, and bargain over prices. More specific examples are wage posting, Nash bargaining, and directed search. Next we turn to growth models of heterogeneous firms and study the implications of frictions for static and dynamic efficiency. Special attention will be paid to frictions in capital investment.

column1: Management accounting is at the heart of high-quality decision-making. Modern financial managers are not only concerned with how cost data are transformed into accounting information, but more importantly how to use cost accounting information to support decision-making and accomplish organizational goals.

Management accounting is therefore much more than number crunching – ultimately its function is to gather and analyse information to advise strategy and drive sustainable business success. This course provides students with a good exposure to managerial accounting tools and techniques and their practical application to business managers. Students in this course will learn how to combine financial and non-financial data to paint a complete picture of the business and to support several aspects of management. Emphasis will also be given to the emerging role of business analytics to inform business decisions. In addition to accounting and analytical skills, management accounting requires an understanding of the organisation, its business model, its strategic context and its competitive position, as well as being alert to the organisation’s social and environmental responsibilities.

The course should develop the student's understanding, skills, and analytic ability in management accounting to the level where she/he can function effectively as a professional management accountant/financial controller in industry, auditing firms, management consulting, or governmental organizations.

column1: Students successfully completing this course will be able to:

column2: • Classify and understand different types of costs (e.g., product costs vs. period costs, direct vs. indirect costs, and fixed vs. variable cost) and identify various concepts of costs (e.g., opportunity costs, sunk costs, marginal costs, average costs)
• Understand the flow of data in an accounting information system, apply data analytics techniques, and interpret results to answer business questions
• Develop cost functions, execute a cost-volume-profit analysis and apply alternative cost accounting systems
• Describe a typical organization's process of budget administration and compose the different elements of the master budget
• Distinguish between static and flexible budgets, execute variance analysis to assess organizational performance and formulate improvement plans
• Analyse and evaluate the organizational implications of alternative models of responsibility accounting and performance measurement systems
• Select what accounting information is useful to support internal decision making, planning and control

column1: ​Management Control Systems (MCS) form the bridge between the organization’s strategy and its operations/services. Their purpose is to align managerial behaviour and decision making with organizational strategic goals. Although financial management tools are typically crucial  in an organization’s MCS, the design and use of a MCS does not only require an understanding of accounting techniques. It should also be based on a thorough understanding of how managerial behaviour is influenced by relevant control system elements, such as target setting, performance measurement and monetary incentives. Indeed, as the proper design of MCS is paramount for organizational performance, organizational failure can often be attributed to a poor design or implementation of the organization’s management control system. Past scandals such as the collapse of Enron and the recent crisis in the financial sector can be directly traced back to failures in MCS design. The emphasis of the course is on the analysis and understanding of the drivers of managerial (rational and irrational) decision making in complex organizations rather than on the application of accounting tools often associated with financial management.

The course strongly focuses on the managerial issues faced by CFOs of multinational companies. Meetings are case-based: students discuss (financial) management control topics in close relation to case studies of multinational companies. The assignments/tests will allow students to show their theoretical knowledge, but also their understanding of how to apply it to real-life case situations.

column1: By the end of the course, students should be familiar with:

column2: • Requirements for effective management control systems to induce goal-congruent behaviour
• Elements of a well-designed Management Control System (MCS)
• Fit between the firm’s MCS and its environment
• Psychological and economic views on decision-making in contemporary organisations

column1: This course is only open for students who started the MScBA Accounting and Financial Management in academic year 2021-2022 or earlier. The course is not part of the curriculum of the academic year 2022-2023.

Management Control is about influencing the behavior of managers to act in line with the organization’s strategic objectives. In this course, we discuss what alternatives organizations have for ensuring good control, and how organizations should choose among control system alternatives. The main emphasis throughout the course will be on financial results control systems, which provide the dominant form of control in the vast majority of organizations. Topics covered include responsibility structures, target setting (as part of organizations’ planning and budgeting processes), performance measurement and evaluation, and the assignment of various forms of organizational rewards (including performance-dependent compensation).

Illustrations based on real-world cases are discussed, demonstrating when particular control systems are effective, and when they lead to dysfunctional managerial behavior. Ample attention is also paid to the fit with the organizational context, such as the strategy, structure, and culture. The latter part of the course extends the key notions of management control from the intra-organizational level to the inter-organizational level, highlighting some of the issues involved in the control of new collaborative settings and configurations, such as joint-ventures and various types of alliances, often involving global alliance partners.

Overall, this course is intended to broaden and deepen your conceptual and technical understanding of accounting as it is used for management control purposes. It will help you learn to make business decisions, evaluate organizational performance, or evaluate others (and/or be evaluated) through the use of financial and nonfinancial information. These are essential skills for your future career, be it in the position of managers, management consultants, or specialists in staff functions such as controllers, auditors, or human resource specialists. </body>

column1: On completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand the purpose of a management accounting & control system, and how it relates to strategy implementation;
• Describe and evaluate different types of controls dependent on the type of organization and its structure;
• List the crucial characteristics of performance measures and apply the principles of performance measurement;
• Identify the (dys-)functional effects of performance measurement and reward systems;
• Evaluate and use different performance measurement and evaluation techniques, such as EVA and BSC;
• Describe the logic behind contingency theory and exemplify how situational factors might influence the management control system in an organization;
• Explain the main drivers behind the development and increased importance of inter-organizational relationships and related control issues;
• Approach management control related questions from different theoretical perspectives, using economic and behavioral theory;
• Identify, analyze and provide solutions to management control problems covered in this course.

column1: The content is organized into 6 modules (the fourth one over 2 weeks), covering the following

column2: • Introduction to quantitative decision making via Decision Trees ( Introduction to mathematical modelling, strengths and limitations, time structure of decisions, handling uncertainty). Introduction to Python.
• Linear Programming (Formulating and solving Linear Programs. The graphical method. Solving LP’s using Gurobi.)
• Sensitivity Analysis (Analyzing sensitivity of LP solutions with respect to data.)
• Integer Programming (Modeling discrete decisions. Formulating Integer programs, understanding why IP’s are harder to solve, modelling with binary variables)
• Incorporating Uncertainty in Linear Programming (2-stage stochastic programming, deterministic equivalent, non-anticipativity, connection with decision trees)
• Monte Carlo Simulation (Understanding the flexibility of simulation, creating and running simulation models in Python)

column1: Through the course, we will apply the learned tools to areas such as operations and transportation logistics.

Each week we will have 2 sessions. The first session of each week (1 hours and 45 minutes) will be a Lecture. The second session (1 hours 45 minutes) will be a workshop. You will work on problems/cases and I will help you with questions/clarifications. Solutions to these problems will become available post-class.

column1: In this course you will learn how to use data and management science tools and models to make informed decisions in a variety of business contexts. Models are approximations, reflecting the most relevant, but not all, aspects of reality. You will learn to decouple the assumptions from the analysis and develop a well grounded appreciation for the value-adding potential of quantitative thinking but also the need to critically evaluate model outputs.
After this course, students will be able to..

column2: • Recognize the types of business problems that can be solved using optimization and simulation methods
• Understand how optimization and simulation can add value to business and provide a competitive edge
• Formulate optimization models and solve them using Excel
• Formulate simulation models and run them using Excel
• Analyze sensitivity of solutions of decision models
• Recommend the best course of action based on solutions of optimization and simulation models
